passage.title: Passage 1
passage.text:
(1). The human genome is composed of hereditary material known as DNA or deoxyribonucleic acid. The chemical structure of DNA was established in 1953, making the discovery of DNA a relatively recent development in the scientific community. It was not long after the mapping of the human genome in 2003 that genome editing became of great interest to scientists around the world. Genome editing aims to modify an organism’s DNA; with the use of advanced technologies, genetic material can be added or removed at specific locations in the genome to alter the organism’s DNA sequence. Various approaches to genetic modification have been explored: for instance, homologous recombination has been commonly used in mouse embryonic stem cells to produce germline knockout or knock-in mice, and zinc finger nucleases (ZFNs) have also been used to cleave specific sites in an organism’s genome. Recently, developments in genome-editing technology have led to the discovery of bacterial adaptive immune systems, known as Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats (CRISPR).

(2). The CRISPR approach is based on a naturally occurring immune response in bacteria. When viruses attack bacteria, the bacterial immune system secures portions of the viral DNA and stores them as DNA segments called CRISPR arrays; these viral DNA segments can help the bacteria identify and fight off new viral infections. If a viral infection occurs, bacteria use the CRISPR arrays to develop RNA segments that match parts of the viral genetic code – these RNA segments are called guide RNAs (gRNA). gRNAs bind to the viral DNA and guide Cas9 enzymes, or other nuclease enzymes, to cleave the DNA. The cleaving of viral DNA segments causes the virus to be inactivated and allows the bacteria to attack the virus. In recent years, researchers have discovered that the CRISPR-Cas9 system can be modified to cut not just viral DNA but essentially any DNA sequence in a test tube, as well as in the nucleus of a living cell.

(3). Due to rapidly growing populations, severe weather, and diminished agricultural land, scientists have turned towards genome editing techniques to establish food security. One such example is the CRISPR-Cas9 technique, the discovery of which has opened possibilities for altering genetic sequences in both plant and animal systems. The CRISPR-Cas9 system allows researchers to modify the genome of crops to increase crop production, quality, and crop diversity. In recent years, Joyce Van Eck and Zach Lippman, collaborators at the Boyce Thompson Institute in Ithaca, New York, have applied the CRISPR-Cas9 gene-editing technology to try and control the size of the ground cherry plant (unlike its relative, the tomato, the ground cherry is prone to produce small fruits that fall to the ground before ripening). Van Eck and Lippman used the CRISPR-Cas9 system to modify the ground cherry’s genome so that it may reproduce some of the tomato’s genetic traits. Due to the characterization of many genome sequences, it is now possible to perform gene editing on crops such as cotton, soybeans, tomatoes, potatoes, and even grapes. Although the use of CRISPR-Cas9 has become increasingly popular in the agricultural industry, very few crop species have been thoroughly researched. Most gene editing is currently being tested on model species such as the Arabidopsis, rice, and tobacco plants. Scientists aim to continue research into altering crop genomes in the future.

(4). Researchers are also exploring the application of the CRISPR-Cas9 system in human gene therapy, gene therapy being an experimental technique that introduces or replaces genetic material to treat genetic disorders. Many disorders are caused by single-gene mutations and can, in theory, be treated using the CRISPR-Cas9 system. In 2014, scientists implemented CRISPR-Cas9 mediated genome editing to treat the hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. Although there are alternate antiviral treatments available for patients with HBV, these treatments are not entirely successful in removing the virus. The CRISPR-Cas9 system was able to significantly reduce the production of hepatitis B virus surface proteins, indicating its ability to eliminate the virus. The use of genome editing technology is also being considered for the treatment of other viruses, such as HIV and herpes.

(5). Beyond genome editing, CRISPR-Cas9 has shown promising results in controlling gene expression. Scientists remodelled the technology by creating a catalytically inactive Cas-9 enzyme known as dCas9. In this remodel, the dCas9 enzyme continues to identify and bind to target DNA just as a regular Cas-9 enzyme does. However, instead of cleaving the DNA at the target site, dCas9 remains bound to the DNA sequence, disturbing the RNA polymerase and any transcription factors that intend to bind to the sequence. This system, referred to as CRISPR interference (CRISPRi), can therefore inhibit the expression of various genes without changing the genome itself.

(6). Although the CRISPR-Cas9 system is regarded as one of the most versatile methods in genome editing technology, there are some challenges researchers are facing with the system. One major disadvantage of the CRISPR-Cas9 method is off-target mutations. In a large genome, it is likely that the DNA will contain several sequences that are homologous to the target sequence, and the challenge with the CRISPR-Cas9 system is that it may result in the cleaving of those homologous sequences, causing unwanted mutations and cell death. To avoid such an outcome, researchers are selecting target sequences that have a minimal number of off-target sites. As such, in 2014, scientists developed a searching tool known as CasOT, which locates possible off-target sites throughout the genome, and this has helped to reduce the number of off-target mutations.

(7). Another challenge researchers have come across with the CRISPR-Cas9 model is its PAM dependence. With the presence of gRNA, CRISPR-Cas9 can theoretically be used for any DNA sequence but for CRISPR-Cas9 to maintain specificity, there must be a 2- 5 nucleotide PAM sequence present downstream from the target sequence itself. This PAM dependence limits the number of sites that may be considered target sequences within the CRISPR-Cas9 model, though it does benefit the gene-editing technology as it promotes increased specificity of CRISPR-Cas9. As a result, the model that requires a longer PAM sequence will have a reduced occurrence of off-target mutations.

(8). Scientists are attempting to improve the CRISPR-Cas9 model to move forward in the field of gene editing, but given the nature of the field, there are many ethical concerns that need to be taken into consideration. For instance, the implementation of CRISPR-Cas9 in agriculture raises the same issues that were brought forth during the rise of genetically modified organisms (GMOs). Many individuals feel troubled by the idea of consuming genetically modified and processed foods, though scientists argue that while GMOs were dominated by corporations, the CRISPR-Cas9 technology will be used for academic purposes. Unlike the GMO industry, scientists claim that CRISPR-Cas9 will be transparent and accessible, giving academic researchers and non-profit institutions the opportunity to study the technology as well.

(9). Another ethical concern that may be raised is the use of genome editing technology on humans. While there are several cases of human trials, some researchers in China have gone so far as to implement CRISPR-Cas9 on embryos to select for protection against HIV. Researchers at the National Institutes of Health worry that germline genome editing is not well-researched and, as a result, may pose a safety concern for testing on embryos; others have moral or religious objections against human embryo testing, and, as a result, federal funds are currently not being used for any gene-editing research on embryos. However, many countries are continuing to fund CRISPR research on viable and non-viable embryos to try and gain a better understanding of how germline editing affects future generations. In general, bioethicists and researchers currently agree that studies testing human genome editing for reproductive purposes should be avoided.

(10). Although there remains a lot of research to be done, the CRISPR-Cas9 mediated genome editing technology is a promising tool that has the potential to increase crop diversity, control gene expression, and even treat genetic disorders. Due to its increased specificity and versatility, CRISPR-Cas9 is quickly becoming a popular system among researchers. It is hoped that advances in technology may lead to a future where scientists can successfully treat genetic diseases and eliminate life-threatening viruses altogether.

question.text: When was the human genome mapped?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, note that the information requested in the question stem applies to relatively basic information about the human genome (when the human genome was mapped). As this is the case, we can presume that such information will be found early in the passage, as the subject of the text is “genome editing.” Indeed, paragraph 1 reads: “The chemical structure of DNA was established in 1953, making the discovery of DNA a relatively recent development in the scientific community. It was not long after the mapping of the human genome in 2003 that genome editing became of great interest to scientists around the world.” This tells us that the human genome was mapped in 2003. Therefore, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. 1936 – is incorrect because this year is not mentioned in the passage. Option B. 1953 – is incorrect because, according to paragraph 1, this was the year that the chemical structure of DNA was established, not the date that the human genome was mapped. Option D. 2006 – is incorrect because this year is not mentioned in the passage.

question.text: Which of the following cites a reason that federal funds are not being directed toward gene-editing research on embryos at present?

options.label: A.
options.text: There is concern about the inadequate research done into germline genome-editing

options.label: B.
options.text: The federal budget does not have space for gene-editing research on embryos

options.label: C.
options.text: There are safety issues for those carrying out CRISPR-Cas9 on embryos

options.label: D.
options.text: Certain religions are ethically opposed to human genome-testing

correct_answer_text: There is concern about the inadequate research done into germline genome-editing

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should locate the paragraph or paragraphs in the passage that mentions embryo testing. It can be presumed that a discussion of funding for research on embryos will be discussed in such a section. Embryo testing is mentioned only in paragraph 9: “Researchers at the National Institutes of Health worry that germline genome editing is not well-researched and as a result, may pose a safety concern for testing on embryos; others have moral or religious objections against human embryo testing, and, as a result, federal funds are currently not being used for any gene-editing research on embryos.” This tells us that because researchers at the National Institutes of Health worry that germline genome editing is not well-researched and because others have moral or religious objections against human embryo testing, federal funds are currently not in use for gene-editing research on embryos. However, only the concerns of the National Institute of Health are mentioned as a reason in the option choices. Therefore, Option A is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. The federal budget does not have space for gene-editing research on embryos – is incorrect because paragraph 9 specifies that federal funds are currently not being used for any gene-editing research on embryos because of worries from the National Institute of Health and because of the religious and moral objections of certain individuals, NOT because of budgeting issues. Option C. There are safety issues for those carrying out CRISPR-Cas9 on embryos – is incorrect because, while paragraph 9 does mention that “some researchers in China have gone so far as to implement CRISPR-Cas9 on embryos,” paragraph 9 also states that “researchers at the National Institutes of Health worry that germline genome editing is not well-researched, and as a result, may pose a safety concern for testing on embryos; others have moral or religious objections against human embryo testing, and, as a result, federal funds are currently not being used for any gene-editing research on embryos.” Thus, the reason that federal funds are not being used for gene-editing research on embryos is unrelated to safety concerns with CRISPR-Cas9 specifically. Option D. Certain religions are ethically opposed to human genome-testing – is incorrect because paragraph 9 states that the religious individuals have issues with embryo testing specifically, not human-genome testing overall.

question.text: What is a Cas9 enzyme?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should search the passage for a preliminary mention of the term “Cas9.” It can be presumed that a description of Cas9 will follow the initial appearance of the term in the passage. Cas9 is first mentioned in paragraph 2: “If a viral infection occurs, bacteria use the CRISPR arrays to develop RNA segments that match parts of the viral genetic code – these RNA segments are called guide RNAs (gRNA). gRNAs bind to the viral DNA and guide Cas9 enzymes , or other nuclease enzymes, to cleave the DNA.” This tells us that a Cas9 enzyme is a nuclease enzyme. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. A CRISPR array – is incorrect because a CRISPR array is a DNA segment, not an enzyme. Option C. A viral protein – is incorrect because the Cas9 enzyme is a part of the bacterial immune system and thus cannot be classified as a viral protein. Option D. A DNA sequence – is incorrect because the Cas9 enzyme is not a DNA sequence.

For instance, the implementation of CRISPR-Cas9 in agriculture raises the same issues that were brought forth during the rise of genetically modified organisms (GMOs). Many individuals feel troubled by the idea of consuming genetically modified and processed foods, though scientists argue that while GMOs were dominated by corporations, the CRISPR-Cas9 technology will be used for academic purposes. Unlike the GMO industry, scientists claim that CRISPR-Cas9 will be transparent and accessible, giving academic researchers and non-profit institutions the opportunity to study the technology as well.

(9). Another ethical concern that may be raised is the use of genome editing technology on humans. While there are several cases of human trials, some researchers in China have gone so far as to implement CRISPR-Cas9 on embryos to select for protection against HIV. Researchers at the National Institutes of Health worry that germline genome editing is not well-researched and, as a result, may pose a safety concern for testing on embryos; others have moral or religious objections against human embryo testing, and, as a result, federal funds are currently not being used for any gene-editing research on embryos. However, many countries are continuing to fund CRISPR research on viable and non-viable embryos to try and gain a better understanding of how germline editing affects future generations. In general, bioethicists and researchers currently agree that studies testing human genome editing for reproductive purposes should be avoided.

(10). Although there remains a lot of research to be done, the CRISPR-Cas9 mediated genome editing technology is a promising tool that has the potential to increase crop diversity, control gene expression, and even treat genetic disorders. Due to its increased specificity and versatility, CRISPR-Cas9 is quickly becoming a popular system among researchers. It is hoped that advances in technology may lead to a future where scientists can successfully treat genetic diseases and eliminate life-threatening viruses altogether.

passage.title: Passage 1
passage.text:
(1). The human genome is composed of hereditary material known as DNA or deoxyribonucleic acid. The chemical structure of DNA was established in 1953, making the discovery of DNA a relatively recent development in the scientific community. It was not long after the mapping of the human genome in 2003 that genome editing became of great interest to scientists around the world. Genome editing aims to modify an organism’s DNA; with the use of advanced technologies, genetic material can be added or removed at specific locations in the genome to alter the organism’s DNA sequence. Various approaches to genetic modification have been explored: for instance, homologous recombination has been commonly used in mouse embryonic stem cells to produce germline knockout or knock-in mice, and zinc finger nucleases (ZFNs) have also been used to cleave specific sites in an organism’s genome. Recently, developments in genome-editing technology have led to the discovery of bacterial adaptive immune systems, known as Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats (CRISPR).

(2). The CRISPR approach is based on a naturally occurring immune response in bacteria. When viruses attack bacteria, the bacterial immune system secures portions of the viral DNA and stores them as DNA segments called CRISPR arrays; these viral DNA segments can help the bacteria identify and fight off new viral infections. If a viral infection occurs, bacteria use the CRISPR arrays to develop RNA segments that match parts of the viral genetic code – these RNA segments are called guide RNAs (gRNA). gRNAs bind to the viral DNA and guide Cas9 enzymes, or other nuclease enzymes, to cleave the DNA. The cleaving of viral DNA segments causes the virus to be inactivated and allows the bacteria to attack the virus. In recent years, researchers have discovered that the CRISPR-Cas9 system can be modified to cut not just viral DNA but essentially any DNA sequence in a test tube, as well as in the nucleus of a living cell.

(3). Due to rapidly growing populations, severe weather, and diminished agricultural land, scientists have turned towards genome editing techniques to establish food security. One such example is the CRISPR-Cas9 technique, the discovery of which has opened possibilities for altering genetic sequences in both plant and animal systems. The CRISPR-Cas9 system allows researchers to modify the genome of crops to increase crop production, quality, and crop diversity. In recent years, Joyce Van Eck and Zach Lippman, collaborators at the Boyce Thompson Institute in Ithaca, New York, have applied the CRISPR-Cas9 gene-editing technology to try and control the size of the ground cherry plant (unlike its relative, the tomato, the ground cherry is prone to produce small fruits that fall to the ground before ripening). Van Eck and Lippman used the CRISPR-Cas9 system to modify the ground cherry’s genome so that it may reproduce some of the tomato’s genetic traits. Due to the characterization of many genome sequences, it is now possible to perform gene editing on crops such as cotton, soybeans, tomatoes, potatoes, and even grapes. Although the use of CRISPR-Cas9 has become increasingly popular in the agricultural industry, very few crop species have been thoroughly researched. Most gene editing is currently being tested on model species such as the Arabidopsis, rice, and tobacco plants. Scientists aim to continue research into altering crop genomes in the future.

(4). Researchers are also exploring the application of the CRISPR-Cas9 system in human gene therapy, gene therapy being an experimental technique that introduces or replaces genetic material to treat genetic disorders. Many disorders are caused by single-gene mutations and can, in theory, be treated using the CRISPR-Cas9 system. In 2014, scientists implemented CRISPR-Cas9 mediated genome editing to treat the hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. Although there are alternate antiviral treatments available for patients with HBV, these treatments are not entirely successful in removing the virus. The CRISPR-Cas9 system was able to significantly reduce the production of hepatitis B virus surface proteins, indicating its ability to eliminate the virus. The use of genome editing technology is also being considered for the treatment of other viruses, such as HIV and herpes.

(5). Beyond genome editing, CRISPR-Cas9 has shown promising results in controlling gene expression. Scientists remodelled the technology by creating a catalytically inactive Cas-9 enzyme known as dCas9. In this remodel, the dCas9 enzyme continues to identify and bind to target DNA just as a regular Cas-9 enzyme does. However, instead of cleaving the DNA at the target site, dCas9 remains bound to the DNA sequence, disturbing the RNA polymerase and any transcription factors that intend to bind to the sequence. This system, referred to as CRISPR interference (CRISPRi), can therefore inhibit the expression of various genes without changing the genome itself.

(6). Although the CRISPR-Cas9 system is regarded as one of the most versatile methods in genome editing technology, there are some challenges researchers are facing with the system. One major disadvantage of the CRISPR-Cas9 method is off-target mutations. In a large genome, it is likely that the DNA will contain several sequences that are homologous to the target sequence, and the challenge with the CRISPR-Cas9 system is that it may result in the cleaving of those homologous sequences, causing unwanted mutations and cell death. To avoid such an outcome, researchers are selecting target sequences that have a minimal number of off-target sites. As such, in 2014, scientists developed a searching tool known as CasOT, which locates possible off-target sites throughout the genome, and this has helped to reduce the number of off-target mutations.

(7). Another challenge researchers have come across with the CRISPR-Cas9 model is its PAM dependence. With the presence of gRNA, CRISPR-Cas9 can theoretically be used for any DNA sequence but for CRISPR-Cas9 to maintain specificity, there must be a 2- 5 nucleotide PAM sequence present downstream from the target sequence itself. This PAM dependence limits the number of sites that may be considered target sequences within the CRISPR-Cas9 model, though it does benefit the gene-editing technology as it promotes increased specificity of CRISPR-Cas9. As a result, the model that requires a longer PAM sequence will have a reduced occurrence of off-target mutations.

(8). Scientists are attempting to improve the CRISPR-Cas9 model to move forward in the field of gene editing, but given the nature of the field, there are many ethical concerns that need to be taken into consideration. For instance, the implementation of CRISPR-Cas9 in agriculture raises the same issues that were brought forth during the rise of genetically modified organisms (GMOs). Many individuals feel troubled by the idea of consuming genetically modified and processed foods, though scientists argue that while GMOs were dominated by corporations, the CRISPR-Cas9 technology will be used for academic purposes. Unlike the GMO industry, scientists claim that CRISPR-Cas9 will be transparent and accessible, giving academic researchers and non-profit institutions the opportunity to study the technology as well.

(9). Another ethical concern that may be raised is the use of genome editing technology on humans. While there are several cases of human trials, some researchers in China have gone so far as to implement CRISPR-Cas9 on embryos to select for protection against HIV. Researchers at the National Institutes of Health worry that germline genome editing is not well-researched and, as a result, may pose a safety concern for testing on embryos; others have moral or religious objections against human embryo testing, and, as a result, federal funds are currently not being used for any gene-editing research on embryos. However, many countries are continuing to fund CRISPR research on viable and non-viable embryos to try and gain a better understanding of how germline editing affects future generations. In general, bioethicists and researchers currently agree that studies testing human genome editing for reproductive purposes should be avoided.

(10). Although there remains a lot of research to be done, the CRISPR-Cas9 mediated genome editing technology is a promising tool that has the potential to increase crop diversity, control gene expression, and even treat genetic disorders. Due to its increased specificity and versatility, CRISPR-Cas9 is quickly becoming a popular system among researchers. It is hoped that advances in technology may lead to a future where scientists can successfully treat genetic diseases and eliminate life-threatening viruses altogether.

question.text: Which of the following crops are model species used to study gene editing?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should locate the paragraph or paragraphs in the passage that discusses genome editing on plant species. Paragraph 3 discusses this topic: “Due to the characterization of many genome sequences, it is now possible to perform gene editing on crops such as cotton, soybeans, tomatoes, potatoes, and even grapes…Most gene editing is currently being tested on model species such as the Arabidopsis , rice , and tobacco plants .” Although paragraph 3 tells us that it is POSSIBLE to perform gene editing on cotton, soybeans, tomatoes, potatoes, and grapes, it specifies that model species being used for gene editing are the Arabidopsis, rice, and tobacco plants. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Soybeans, Arabidopsis, tomatoes – is incorrect because soybeans and tomatoes are not listed as model species. Option B. Cotton, potatoes, soybeans – is incorrect because neither cotton, potatoes, nor soybeans are listed as model species. Option C. Rice, tobacco, cotton – is incorrect because cotton is not a model species used in the research of gene editing.

question.text: What message is the author attempting to convey in paragraph 8?

options.label: A.
options.text: CRISPR-Cas9 technology and GMOs are equally harmful

options.label: B.
options.text: CRISPR-Cas9 is seen as more unambiguous and less controversial than GMOs

options.label: C.
options.text: CRISPR-Cas9 is set to become the leading technique in genetic modification

options.label: D.
options.text: CRISPR-Cas9 is more morally questionable than GMOs

correct_answer_text: CRISPR-Cas9 is seen as more unambiguous and less controversial than GMOs

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should first read paragraph 8 carefully before attempting to ascertain the main points made in this section of the text; by combining these main points, we can then deduce the message that the author is trying to convey. Paragraph 8 reads: “Scientists are attempting to improve the CRISPR-Cas9 model to move forward in the field of gene editing, but given the nature of the field, there are many ethical concerns that need to be taken into consideration. For instance, the implementation of CRISPR-Cas9 in agriculture raises the same issues that were brought forth during the rise of genetically modified organisms (GMOs). Many individuals feel troubled by the idea of consuming genetically modified and processed foods, though scientists argue that while GMOs were dominated by corporations, the CRISPR-Cas9 technology will be used for academic purposes. Unlike the GMO industry, scientists claim that CRISPR-Cas9 will be transparent and accessible, giving academic researchers and non-profit institutions the opportunity to study the technology as well.” The main points of this paragraph are as follows: If we combine these points, we can say that the author is attempting to convey the fact that, although people are concerned about the CRISPR-Cas9 model, scientists argue that it will be more transparent and less worrisome than GMOs. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. CRISPR-Cas9 technology and GMOs are equally harmful – is incorrect because this is not implied in the passage. The author states, “while GMOs were dominated by corporations, the CRISPR-Cas9 technology was used for academic purposes,” which does not imply that one technology is as harmful as the other. Option C. CRISPR-Cas9 is set to become the leading technique in genetic modification – is incorrect because this is not implied in the passage. The author states, “Unlike the GMO industry, scientists claim that CRISPR-Cas9 will be transparent and accessible,” which doesn’t imply that CRISPR–Cas9 will necessarily become the leading genetic modification technique, only that it would be more transparent than GMOs. Option D. CRISPR-Cas9 is more morally questionable than GMOs – is incorrect because in paragraph 8, the author argues that GMOs are dominated by corporations while CRISPR-Cas9 is used for academics and that it is transparent and accessible. This doesn’t imply that CRISPR-Cas9 is more morally questionable but that GMOs are more concerning.

One such example is the CRISPR-Cas9 technique, the discovery of which has opened possibilities for altering genetic sequences in both plant and animal systems. The CRISPR-Cas9 system allows researchers to modify the genome of crops to increase crop production, quality, and crop diversity. In recent years, Joyce Van Eck and Zach Lippman, collaborators at the Boyce Thompson Institute in Ithaca, New York, have applied the CRISPR-Cas9 gene-editing technology to try and control the size of the ground cherry plant (unlike its relative, the tomato, the ground cherry is prone to produce small fruits that fall to the ground before ripening). Van Eck and Lippman used the CRISPR-Cas9 system to modify the ground cherry’s genome so that it may reproduce some of the tomato’s genetic traits. Due to the characterization of many genome sequences, it is now possible to perform gene editing on crops such as cotton, soybeans, tomatoes, potatoes, and even grapes. Although the use of CRISPR-Cas9 has become increasingly popular in the agricultural industry, very few crop species have been thoroughly researched. Most gene editing is currently being tested on model species such as the Arabidopsis, rice, and tobacco plants. Scientists aim to continue research into altering crop genomes in the future.

(4). Researchers are also exploring the application of the CRISPR-Cas9 system in human gene therapy, gene therapy being an experimental technique that introduces or replaces genetic material to treat genetic disorders. Many disorders are caused by single-gene mutations and can, in theory, be treated using the CRISPR-Cas9 system. In 2014, scientists implemented CRISPR-Cas9 mediated genome editing to treat the hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. Although there are alternate antiviral treatments available for patients with HBV, these treatments are not entirely successful in removing the virus. The CRISPR-Cas9 system was able to significantly reduce the production of hepatitis B virus surface proteins, indicating its ability to eliminate the virus. The use of genome editing technology is also being considered for the treatment of other viruses, such as HIV and herpes.

(5). Beyond genome editing, CRISPR-Cas9 has shown promising results in controlling gene expression. Scientists remodelled the technology by creating a catalytically inactive Cas-9 enzyme known as dCas9. In this remodel, the dCas9 enzyme continues to identify and bind to target DNA just as a regular Cas-9 enzyme does. However, instead of cleaving the DNA at the target site, dCas9 remains bound to the DNA sequence, disturbing the RNA polymerase and any transcription factors that intend to bind to the sequence. This system, referred to as CRISPR interference (CRISPRi), can therefore inhibit the expression of various genes without changing the genome itself.

(6). Although the CRISPR-Cas9 system is regarded as one of the most versatile methods in genome editing technology, there are some challenges researchers are facing with the system. One major disadvantage of the CRISPR-Cas9 method is off-target mutations. In a large genome, it is likely that the DNA will contain several sequences that are homologous to the target sequence, and the challenge with the CRISPR-Cas9 system is that it may result in the cleaving of those homologous sequences, causing unwanted mutations and cell death. To avoid such an outcome, researchers are selecting target sequences that have a minimal number of off-target sites. As such, in 2014, scientists developed a searching tool known as CasOT, which locates possible off-target sites throughout the genome, and this has helped to reduce the number of off-target mutations.

(7). Another challenge researchers have come across with the CRISPR-Cas9 model is its PAM dependence. With the presence of gRNA, CRISPR-Cas9 can theoretically be used for any DNA sequence but for CRISPR-Cas9 to maintain specificity, there must be a 2- 5 nucleotide PAM sequence present downstream from the target sequence itself. This PAM dependence limits the number of sites that may be considered target sequences within the CRISPR-Cas9 model, though it does benefit the gene-editing technology as it promotes increased specificity of CRISPR-Cas9. As a result, the model that requires a longer PAM sequence will have a reduced occurrence of off-target mutations.

(8). Scientists are attempting to improve the CRISPR-Cas9 model to move forward in the field of gene editing, but given the nature of the field, there are many ethical concerns that need to be taken into consideration. For instance, the implementation of CRISPR-Cas9 in agriculture raises the same issues that were brought forth during the rise of genetically modified organisms (GMOs). Many individuals feel troubled by the idea of consuming genetically modified and processed foods, though scientists argue that while GMOs were dominated by corporations, the CRISPR-Cas9 technology will be used for academic purposes. Unlike the GMO industry, scientists claim that CRISPR-Cas9 will be transparent and accessible, giving academic researchers and non-profit institutions the opportunity to study the technology as well.

(9). Another ethical concern that may be raised is the use of genome editing technology on humans. While there are several cases of human trials, some researchers in China have gone so far as to implement CRISPR-Cas9 on embryos to select for protection against HIV. Researchers at the National Institutes of Health worry that germline genome editing is not well-researched and, as a result, may pose a safety concern for testing on embryos; others have moral or religious objections against human embryo testing, and, as a result, federal funds are currently not being used for any gene-editing research on embryos. However, many countries are continuing to fund CRISPR research on viable and non-viable embryos to try and gain a better understanding of how germline editing affects future generations. In general, bioethicists and researchers currently agree that studies testing human genome editing for reproductive purposes should be avoided.

(10). Although there remains a lot of research to be done, the CRISPR-Cas9 mediated genome editing technology is a promising tool that has the potential to increase crop diversity, control gene expression, and even treat genetic disorders. Due to its increased specificity and versatility, CRISPR-Cas9 is quickly becoming a popular system among researchers. It is hoped that advances in technology may lead to a future where scientists can successfully treat genetic diseases and eliminate life-threatening viruses altogether.

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, it is useful to apply critical thinking skills. question.text: Each of the following treatment modalities have the potential to reduce viral protein expression EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should locate the paragraph or paragraphs in the passage discussing treatment methods for disorders and diseases that use genome editing. If we note that this topic is discussed in paragraphs 4 and 5, we should then scan these paragraphs for information regarding the reduction of viral protein expression. Paragraph 4 reads: “In 2014, scientists implemented CRISPR-Cas9 mediated genome editing to treat the hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. Although there are alternate antiviral treatments available for patients with HBV, these treatments are not entirely successful in removing the virus. The CRISPR-Cas9 system was able to significantly reduce the production of hepatitis B virus surface proteins, indicating its ability to eliminate the virus.” Paragraph 5 reads: “This system referred to as CRISPR interference (CRISPRi) , can therefore inhibit the expression of various genes without changing the genome itself.” If we next use a process of elimination, we can see that the only option choice NOT listed in paragraphs 4 and 5 is abstinence . Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Antiviral Treatment – is incorrect because according to paragraph four, despite their inability to remove HBV, antiviral treatments are still available for patients. Option C. CRISPRi – is incorrect because in paragraph 5, the author states that it can “inhibit the expression of various genes without changing the genome itself.” Option D. CRISPR-cas9 – is incorrect because, according to paragraph four, “the CRISPR-Cas9 system was able to significantly reduce the production of Hepatitis B virus surface proteins”.

question.text: Each of the following is a component of the CRISPRi system EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should scan the passage for the components listed in the stem before determining which is separate from the CRISPRi system. CasOT is cited as not being part of the CRISPi system, as evidenced in paragraph 6. “…in 2014, scientists developed a searching tool known as CasOT , which locates possible off-target sites throughout the genome, and this has helped to reduce the number of off-target mutations.” This tells us that CasOT was developed by scientists to reduce the number of off-target mutations in the genome; thus, it is NOT a component of the CRISPRi system. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. gRNA – is incorrect because, as the author mentions in the fifth paragraph, “…the dCas9 enzyme continues to identify and bind to target DNA just as a regular Cas-9 enzyme does. However, instead of cleaving the DNA at the target site, dCas9 remains bound to the DNA sequence.” This suggests that the CRISPRi system still involves the gRNA just as the CRISPR-Cas9 system does; thus, this is incorrect. Option B. PAM – is incorrect because, as the author mentions in the fifth paragraph, “…the dCas9 enzyme continues to identify and bind to target DNA just as a regular Cas-9 enzyme does. However, instead of cleaving the DNA at the target site, dCas9 remains bound to the DNA sequence.” This suggests that the CRISPRi system still involves the PAM sequence just as the CRISPR-Cas9 system does; thus, this is incorrect. Option C. dCas9 – is incorrect because, in the fifth paragraph, the author introduces the CRISPRi system. The author mentions that a component of this system is a: “[…] catalytically inactive Cas-9 enzyme known as dCas9.” As it is a component, this cannot be the answer.

passage.title: Passage 1
passage.text:
(1). The human genome is composed of hereditary material known as DNA or deoxyribonucleic acid. The chemical structure of DNA was established in 1953, making the discovery of DNA a relatively recent development in the scientific community. It was not long after the mapping of the human genome in 2003 that genome editing became of great interest to scientists around the world. Genome editing aims to modify an organism’s DNA; with the use of advanced technologies, genetic material can be added or removed at specific locations in the genome to alter the organism’s DNA sequence. Various approaches to genetic modification have been explored: for instance, homologous recombination has been commonly used in mouse embryonic stem cells to produce germline knockout or knock-in mice, and zinc finger nucleases (ZFNs) have also been used to cleave specific sites in an organism’s genome. Recently, developments in genome-editing technology have led to the discovery of bacterial adaptive immune systems, known as Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats (CRISPR).

(2). The CRISPR approach is based on a naturally occurring immune response in bacteria. When viruses attack bacteria, the bacterial immune system secures portions of the viral DNA and stores them as DNA segments called CRISPR arrays; these viral DNA segments can help the bacteria identify and fight off new viral infections. If a viral infection occurs, bacteria use the CRISPR arrays to develop RNA segments that match parts of the viral genetic code – these RNA segments are called guide RNAs (gRNA). gRNAs bind to the viral DNA and guide Cas9 enzymes, or other nuclease enzymes, to cleave the DNA. The cleaving of viral DNA segments causes the virus to be inactivated and allows the bacteria to attack the virus. In recent years, researchers have discovered that the CRISPR-Cas9 system can be modified to cut not just viral DNA but essentially any DNA sequence in a test tube, as well as in the nucleus of a living cell.

(3). Due to rapidly growing populations, severe weather, and diminished agricultural land, scientists have turned towards genome editing techniques to establish food security. One such example is the CRISPR-Cas9 technique, the discovery of which has opened possibilities for altering genetic sequences in both plant and animal systems. The CRISPR-Cas9 system allows researchers to modify the genome of crops to increase crop production, quality, and crop diversity. In recent years, Joyce Van Eck and Zach Lippman, collaborators at the Boyce Thompson Institute in Ithaca, New York, have applied the CRISPR-Cas9 gene-editing technology to try and control the size of the ground cherry plant (unlike its relative, the tomato, the ground cherry is prone to produce small fruits that fall to the ground before ripening). Van Eck and Lippman used the CRISPR-Cas9 system to modify the ground cherry’s genome so that it may reproduce some of the tomato’s genetic traits. Due to the characterization of many genome sequences, it is now possible to perform gene editing on crops such as cotton, soybeans, tomatoes, potatoes, and even grapes. Although the use of CRISPR-Cas9 has become increasingly popular in the agricultural industry, very few crop species have been thoroughly researched. Most gene editing is currently being tested on model species such as the Arabidopsis, rice, and tobacco plants. Scientists aim to continue research into altering crop genomes in the future.

(4). Researchers are also exploring the application of the CRISPR-Cas9 system in human gene therapy, gene therapy being an experimental technique that introduces or replaces genetic material to treat genetic disorders. Many disorders are caused by single-gene mutations and can, in theory, be treated using the CRISPR-Cas9 system. In 2014, scientists implemented CRISPR-Cas9 mediated genome editing to treat the hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. Although there are alternate antiviral treatments available for patients with HBV, these treatments are not entirely successful in removing the virus. The CRISPR-Cas9 system was able to significantly reduce the production of hepatitis B virus surface proteins, indicating its ability to eliminate the virus. The use of genome editing technology is also being considered for the treatment of other viruses, such as HIV and herpes.

(5). Beyond genome editing, CRISPR-Cas9 has shown promising results in controlling gene expression. Scientists remodelled the technology by creating a catalytically inactive Cas-9 enzyme known as dCas9. In this remodel, the dCas9 enzyme continues to identify and bind to target DNA just as a regular Cas-9 enzyme does. However, instead of cleaving the DNA at the target site, dCas9 remains bound to the DNA sequence, disturbing the RNA polymerase and any transcription factors that intend to bind to the sequence. This system, referred to as CRISPR interference (CRISPRi), can therefore inhibit the expression of various genes without changing the genome itself.

(6). Although the CRISPR-Cas9 system is regarded as one of the most versatile methods in genome editing technology, there are some challenges researchers are facing with the system. One major disadvantage of the CRISPR-Cas9 method is off-target mutations. In a large genome, it is likely that the DNA will contain several sequences that are homologous to the target sequence, and the challenge with the CRISPR-Cas9 system is that it may result in the cleaving of those homologous sequences, causing unwanted mutations and cell death. To avoid such an outcome, researchers are selecting target sequences that have a minimal number of off-target sites. As such, in 2014, scientists developed a searching tool known as CasOT, which locates possible off-target sites throughout the genome, and this has helped to reduce the number of off-target mutations.

(7). Another challenge researchers have come across with the CRISPR-Cas9 model is its PAM dependence. With the presence of gRNA, CRISPR-Cas9 can theoretically be used for any DNA sequence but for CRISPR-Cas9 to maintain specificity, there must be a 2- 5 nucleotide PAM sequence present downstream from the target sequence itself. This PAM dependence limits the number of sites that may be considered target sequences within the CRISPR-Cas9 model, though it does benefit the gene-editing technology as it promotes increased specificity of CRISPR-Cas9. As a result, the model that requires a longer PAM sequence will have a reduced occurrence of off-target mutations.

(8). Scientists are attempting to improve the CRISPR-Cas9 model to move forward in the field of gene editing, but given the nature of the field, there are many ethical concerns that need to be taken into consideration. For instance, the implementation of CRISPR-Cas9 in agriculture raises the same issues that were brought forth during the rise of genetically modified organisms (GMOs). Many individuals feel troubled by the idea of consuming genetically modified and processed foods, though scientists argue that while GMOs were dominated by corporations, the CRISPR-Cas9 technology will be used for academic purposes. Unlike the GMO industry, scientists claim that CRISPR-Cas9 will be transparent and accessible, giving academic researchers and non-profit institutions the opportunity to study the technology as well.

(9). Another ethical concern that may be raised is the use of genome editing technology on humans. While there are several cases of human trials, some researchers in China have gone so far as to implement CRISPR-Cas9 on embryos to select for protection against HIV. Researchers at the National Institutes of Health worry that germline genome editing is not well-researched and, as a result, may pose a safety concern for testing on embryos; others have moral or religious objections against human embryo testing, and, as a result, federal funds are currently not being used for any gene-editing research on embryos. However, many countries are continuing to fund CRISPR research on viable and non-viable embryos to try and gain a better understanding of how germline editing affects future generations. In general, bioethicists and researchers currently agree that studies testing human genome editing for reproductive purposes should be avoided.

(10). Although there remains a lot of research to be done, the CRISPR-Cas9 mediated genome editing technology is a promising tool that has the potential to increase crop diversity, control gene expression, and even treat genetic disorders. Due to its increased specificity and versatility, CRISPR-Cas9 is quickly becoming a popular system among researchers. It is hoped that advances in technology may lead to a future where scientists can successfully treat genetic diseases and eliminate life-threatening viruses altogether.

question.text: In a large genome, it is less likely that DNA will carry several identical sequences. Presently, no human trials involving CRISPR research are underway.

options.label: C.
options.text: The first statement is TRUE, the second is FALSE

options.label: D.
options.text: The first statement is FALSE, the second is TRUE

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should first attempt to ascertain the veracity of the initial statement in the question stem. This can be accomplished by searching the passage for references to DNA sequences. If we note that DNA sequences are mentioned in paragraphs 1, 2, 5, and 7, we should then scan each of these paragraphs for mention of identical DNA sequences. These sequences are referenced in paragraph 6. This tells us that in a large genome, it is LIKELY for DNA to contain several identical sequences...thus, the first statement is FALSE. It reads: “In a large genome, it is likely that the DNA will contain several sequences that are homologous to the target sequence.” To verify the second statement in the question stem, we should scan the passage for the paragraph or paragraphs discussing the human trial component of genome editing. This is discussed in paragraph 9. This tells us that there ARE human trials being conducted in CRISPR research…thus, the second statement is FALSE. It reads: “While there are several cases of human trials, some researchers in China have gone so far as to implement CRISPR-Cas9 on embryos to select for protection against HIV.” Altogether, both the first and second statements are false. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Both statements are TRUE – is incorrect because both statements are false. In the 6th paragraph, the author says that “In a large genome, it is likely for DNA to contain several sequences that are homologous to the target sequence.” The statement in the question stem uses the word “unlikely” instead of “likely” and thus is incorrect. In the 9th paragraph, the author says that there are several cases of human trials, which proves the second statement false. Option C. The first statement is TRUE, the second is FALSE – is incorrect because both statements are false. In the 6th paragraph, the author says that “In a large genome, it is likely for DNA to contain several sequences that are homologous to the target sequence.” The statement in the question stem uses the word “unlikely” instead of “likely” and thus is incorrect. Option D. The first statement is FALSE, the second is TRUE – is incorrect because the second statement is false. In the 9th paragraph, the author says that there are several cases of human trials, not zero human trials.

question.text: Which of the following has been used in mouse embryotic stem cells?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should scan the passage for mention of genome editing on mice. This is only mentioned in paragraph 1: “Various approaches to genetic modification have been explored: for instance, homologous recombination has been commonly used in mouse embryonic stem cells to produce germline knockout or knock-in mice, and zinc finger nucleases (ZFNs) have also been used to cleave specific sites in an organism’s genome.” This tells us that homologous recombination has been commonly used in mouse embryonic stem cells. Therefore, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Germline knockout – is incorrect because paragraph 1 states that germline knockout was an outcome of homologous recombination being used in the embryotic stem cells of mice. “Various approaches to genetic modification have been explored: for instance, homologous recombination has been commonly used in mouse embryonic stem cells to produce germline knockout or knock-in mice...” Option B. Zinc finger nucleases – is incorrect because paragraph 1 states that “zinc finger nucleases (ZFNs) have also been used to cleave specific sites in an organism’s genome.” This does not specify that zinc finger nucleases were used in the embryotic stem cells of mice, only that they were used in an “organism’s genome” Option D. Mesenchymal stem cells – is incorrect because this type of stem cell is not mentioned in the passage.

question.text: Which technique is a researcher most likely to employ to reduce off-target mutations?

options.label: A.
options.text: Choosing target sequences with the least number of off-target sites

options.label: B.
options.text: Choosing target sequences with the greatest number of on-target sites

options.label: C.
options.text: Choosing target sequences with no PAM sequences

options.label: D.
options.text: Choosing target sequences with the shortest PAM sequences

correct_answer_text: Choosing target sequences with the least number of off-target sites

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should scan the passage for the key phrase “off-target mutations.” If we note that this type of mutation is discussed in paragraphs 6 and 7, we should then scan each of these sections of the text to determine which discusses the techniques researchers employ to reduce such mutations. This is mentioned in paragraph 6. This tells us that the technique a researcher is most likely to use to reduce off-target mutations is choosing target sequences that have a minimal number of off-target sites. It reads: “In a large genome, it is likely that the DNA will contain several sequences that are homologous to the target sequence and the challenge with the CRISPR-Cas9 system is that it may result in the cleaving of those homologous sequences, causing unwanted mutations and cell death. To avoid such an outcome, researchers are selecting target sequences that have a minimal number of off-target sites.” Therefore, Option A is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Choosing target sequences with the greatest number of on-target sites – is incorrect because the author makes no mention of on-target sites. Instead, in paragraph 6, they mention “researchers are selecting target sequences that have a minimal number of off-target sites.” Option C. Choosing target sequences with no PAM sequences – is incorrect because, in terms of PAM sequences in relation to off-target mutations, the author mentions that longer sequences result in a reduced occurrence of off-target mutations. The option choice mentions no PAM sequences; thus, it is incorrect. Option D. Choosing target sequences with the shortest PAM sequences – is incorrect because, in terms of PAM sequences in relation to off-target mutations, the author mentions that longer sequences result in a reduced occurrence of off-target mutations, not shorter.

Due to the characterization of many genome sequences, it is now possible to perform gene editing on crops such as cotton, soybeans, tomatoes, potatoes, and even grapes. Although the use of CRISPR-Cas9 has become increasingly popular in the agricultural industry, very few crop species have been thoroughly researched. Most gene editing is currently being tested on model species such as the Arabidopsis, rice, and tobacco plants. Scientists aim to continue research into altering crop genomes in the future.

(4). Researchers are also exploring the application of the CRISPR-Cas9 system in human gene therapy, gene therapy being an experimental technique that introduces or replaces genetic material to treat genetic disorders. Many disorders are caused by single-gene mutations and can, in theory, be treated using the CRISPR-Cas9 system. In 2014, scientists implemented CRISPR-Cas9 mediated genome editing to treat the hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. Although there are alternate antiviral treatments available for patients with HBV, these treatments are not entirely successful in removing the virus. The CRISPR-Cas9 system was able to significantly reduce the production of hepatitis B virus surface proteins, indicating its ability to eliminate the virus. The use of genome editing technology is also being considered for the treatment of other viruses, such as HIV and herpes.

(5). Beyond genome editing, CRISPR-Cas9 has shown promising results in controlling gene expression. Scientists remodelled the technology by creating a catalytically inactive Cas-9 enzyme known as dCas9. In this remodel, the dCas9 enzyme continues to identify and bind to target DNA just as a regular Cas-9 enzyme does. However, instead of cleaving the DNA at the target site, dCas9 remains bound to the DNA sequence, disturbing the RNA polymerase and any transcription factors that intend to bind to the sequence. This system, referred to as CRISPR interference (CRISPRi), can therefore inhibit the expression of various genes without changing the genome itself.

(6). Although the CRISPR-Cas9 system is regarded as one of the most versatile methods in genome editing technology, there are some challenges researchers are facing with the system. One major disadvantage of the CRISPR-Cas9 method is off-target mutations. In a large genome, it is likely that the DNA will contain several sequences that are homologous to the target sequence, and the challenge with the CRISPR-Cas9 system is that it may result in the cleaving of those homologous sequences, causing unwanted mutations and cell death. To avoid such an outcome, researchers are selecting target sequences that have a minimal number of off-target sites. As such, in 2014, scientists developed a searching tool known as CasOT, which locates possible off-target sites throughout the genome, and this has helped to reduce the number of off-target mutations.

(7). Another challenge researchers have come across with the CRISPR-Cas9 model is its PAM dependence. With the presence of gRNA, CRISPR-Cas9 can theoretically be used for any DNA sequence but for CRISPR-Cas9 to maintain specificity, there must be a 2- 5 nucleotide PAM sequence present downstream from the target sequence itself. This PAM dependence limits the number of sites that may be considered target sequences within the CRISPR-Cas9 model, though it does benefit the gene-editing technology as it promotes increased specificity of CRISPR-Cas9. As a result, the model that requires a longer PAM sequence will have a reduced occurrence of off-target mutations.

(8). Scientists are attempting to improve the CRISPR-Cas9 model to move forward in the field of gene editing, but given the nature of the field, there are many ethical concerns that need to be taken into consideration. For instance, the implementation of CRISPR-Cas9 in agriculture raises the same issues that were brought forth during the rise of genetically modified organisms (GMOs). Many individuals feel troubled by the idea of consuming genetically modified and processed foods, though scientists argue that while GMOs were dominated by corporations, the CRISPR-Cas9 technology will be used for academic purposes. Unlike the GMO industry, scientists claim that CRISPR-Cas9 will be transparent and accessible, giving academic researchers and non-profit institutions the opportunity to study the technology as well.

(9). Another ethical concern that may be raised is the use of genome editing technology on humans. While there are several cases of human trials, some researchers in China have gone so far as to implement CRISPR-Cas9 on embryos to select for protection against HIV. Researchers at the National Institutes of Health worry that germline genome editing is not well-researched and, as a result, may pose a safety concern for testing on embryos; others have moral or religious objections against human embryo testing, and, as a result, federal funds are currently not being used for any gene-editing research on embryos. However, many countries are continuing to fund CRISPR research on viable and non-viable embryos to try and gain a better understanding of how germline editing affects future generations. In general, bioethicists and researchers currently agree that studies testing human genome editing for reproductive purposes should be avoided.

(10). Although there remains a lot of research to be done, the CRISPR-Cas9 mediated genome editing technology is a promising tool that has the potential to increase crop diversity, control gene expression, and even treat genetic disorders. Due to its increased specificity and versatility, CRISPR-Cas9 is quickly becoming a popular system among researchers. It is hoped that advances in technology may lead to a future where scientists can successfully treat genetic diseases and eliminate life-threatening viruses altogether.

question.text: What must be there be for a CRISPR-Cas9 to maintain specificity?

options.label: A.
options.text: 12-15 nucleotide PAM sequences present downstream from the target sequence

options.label: B.
options.text: 2-5 nucleotide PAM sequences present upstream from the target sequence

options.label: C.
options.text: 2-5 nucleotide gRNA sequences present downstream from the off-target sequence

options.label: D.
options.text: 2-5 nucleotide PAM sequences present downstream from the target sequence

correct_answer_text: 2-5 nucleotide PAM sequences present downstream from the target sequence

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should scan the passage for a paragraph containing both the key term “CRISPR-Cas9” AND the key phrase “maintain specificity.” Paragraph 7 contains both: “…for CRISPR-Cas9 to maintain specificity, there must be a 2-5 nucleotide PAM sequence present downstream from the target sequence itself.” This tells us that, for CRISPR-Cas9 to maintain specificity, there must be 2-5 nucleotide PAM sequences present downstream from the target sequence. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. 12-15 nucleotide PAM sequences present downstream from the target sequence – is incorrect because, in the 7th paragraph, the author states that there must be “a 2-5 nucleotide PAM sequence present downstream from the target sequence itself.” This option choice is incorrect as it mentions 12-15 nucleotide PAM sequences, not 2-5 sequences. Option B. 2-5 nucleotide PAM sequences present upstream from the target sequence – is incorrect because, while this option choice is mostly correct, note that it says “upstream” rather than “downstream from the target sequence itself,” as mentioned in paragraph 7. Option C. 2-5 nucleotide gRNA sequences present downstream from the off-target sequence – is incorrect because, while this option choice is mostly correct, note that it says “gRNA” rather than “PAM sequences present downstream from the off-target sequence,” as mentioned in paragraph 7.

passage.title: Passage 1
passage.text:
(1). The human genome is composed of hereditary material known as DNA or deoxyribonucleic acid. The chemical structure of DNA was established in 1953, making the discovery of DNA a relatively recent development in the scientific community. It was not long after the mapping of the human genome in 2003 that genome editing became of great interest to scientists around the world. Genome editing aims to modify an organism’s DNA; with the use of advanced technologies, genetic material can be added or removed at specific locations in the genome to alter the organism’s DNA sequence. Various approaches to genetic modification have been explored: for instance, homologous recombination has been commonly used in mouse embryonic stem cells to produce germline knockout or knock-in mice, and zinc finger nucleases (ZFNs) have also been used to cleave specific sites in an organism’s genome. Recently, developments in genome-editing technology have led to the discovery of bacterial adaptive immune systems, known as Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats (CRISPR).

(2). The CRISPR approach is based on a naturally occurring immune response in bacteria. When viruses attack bacteria, the bacterial immune system secures portions of the viral DNA and stores them as DNA segments called CRISPR arrays; these viral DNA segments can help the bacteria identify and fight off new viral infections. If a viral infection occurs, bacteria use the CRISPR arrays to develop RNA segments that match parts of the viral genetic code – these RNA segments are called guide RNAs (gRNA). gRNAs bind to the viral DNA and guide Cas9 enzymes, or other nuclease enzymes, to cleave the DNA. The cleaving of viral DNA segments causes the virus to be inactivated and allows the bacteria to attack the virus. In recent years, researchers have discovered that the CRISPR-Cas9 system can be modified to cut not just viral DNA but essentially any DNA sequence in a test tube, as well as in the nucleus of a living cell.

(3). Due to rapidly growing populations, severe weather, and diminished agricultural land, scientists have turned towards genome editing techniques to establish food security. One such example is the CRISPR-Cas9 technique, the discovery of which has opened possibilities for altering genetic sequences in both plant and animal systems. The CRISPR-Cas9 system allows researchers to modify the genome of crops to increase crop production, quality, and crop diversity. In recent years, Joyce Van Eck and Zach Lippman, collaborators at the Boyce Thompson Institute in Ithaca, New York, have applied the CRISPR-Cas9 gene-editing technology to try and control the size of the ground cherry plant (unlike its relative, the tomato, the ground cherry is prone to produce small fruits that fall to the ground before ripening). Van Eck and Lippman used the CRISPR-Cas9 system to modify the ground cherry’s genome so that it may reproduce some of the tomato’s genetic traits. Due to the characterization of many genome sequences, it is now possible to perform gene editing on crops such as cotton, soybeans, tomatoes, potatoes, and even grapes. Although the use of CRISPR-Cas9 has become increasingly popular in the agricultural industry, very few crop species have been thoroughly researched. Most gene editing is currently being tested on model species such as the Arabidopsis, rice, and tobacco plants. Scientists aim to continue research into altering crop genomes in the future.

(4). Researchers are also exploring the application of the CRISPR-Cas9 system in human gene therapy, gene therapy being an experimental technique that introduces or replaces genetic material to treat genetic disorders. Many disorders are caused by single-gene mutations and can, in theory, be treated using the CRISPR-Cas9 system. In 2014, scientists implemented CRISPR-Cas9 mediated genome editing to treat the hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. Although there are alternate antiviral treatments available for patients with HBV, these treatments are not entirely successful in removing the virus. The CRISPR-Cas9 system was able to significantly reduce the production of hepatitis B virus surface proteins, indicating its ability to eliminate the virus. The use of genome editing technology is also being considered for the treatment of other viruses, such as HIV and herpes.

(5). Beyond genome editing, CRISPR-Cas9 has shown promising results in controlling gene expression. Scientists remodelled the technology by creating a catalytically inactive Cas-9 enzyme known as dCas9. In this remodel, the dCas9 enzyme continues to identify and bind to target DNA just as a regular Cas-9 enzyme does. However, instead of cleaving the DNA at the target site, dCas9 remains bound to the DNA sequence, disturbing the RNA polymerase and any transcription factors that intend to bind to the sequence. This system, referred to as CRISPR interference (CRISPRi), can therefore inhibit the expression of various genes without changing the genome itself.

(6). Although the CRISPR-Cas9 system is regarded as one of the most versatile methods in genome editing technology, there are some challenges researchers are facing with the system. One major disadvantage of the CRISPR-Cas9 method is off-target mutations. In a large genome, it is likely that the DNA will contain several sequences that are homologous to the target sequence, and the challenge with the CRISPR-Cas9 system is that it may result in the cleaving of those homologous sequences, causing unwanted mutations and cell death. To avoid such an outcome, researchers are selecting target sequences that have a minimal number of off-target sites. As such, in 2014, scientists developed a searching tool known as CasOT, which locates possible off-target sites throughout the genome, and this has helped to reduce the number of off-target mutations.

(7). Another challenge researchers have come across with the CRISPR-Cas9 model is its PAM dependence. With the presence of gRNA, CRISPR-Cas9 can theoretically be used for any DNA sequence but for CRISPR-Cas9 to maintain specificity, there must be a 2- 5 nucleotide PAM sequence present downstream from the target sequence itself. This PAM dependence limits the number of sites that may be considered target sequences within the CRISPR-Cas9 model, though it does benefit the gene-editing technology as it promotes increased specificity of CRISPR-Cas9. As a result, the model that requires a longer PAM sequence will have a reduced occurrence of off-target mutations.

(8). Scientists are attempting to improve the CRISPR-Cas9 model to move forward in the field of gene editing, but given the nature of the field, there are many ethical concerns that need to be taken into consideration. For instance, the implementation of CRISPR-Cas9 in agriculture raises the same issues that were brought forth during the rise of genetically modified organisms (GMOs). Many individuals feel troubled by the idea of consuming genetically modified and processed foods, though scientists argue that while GMOs were dominated by corporations, the CRISPR-Cas9 technology will be used for academic purposes. Unlike the GMO industry, scientists claim that CRISPR-Cas9 will be transparent and accessible, giving academic researchers and non-profit institutions the opportunity to study the technology as well.

(9). Another ethical concern that may be raised is the use of genome editing technology on humans. While there are several cases of human trials, some researchers in China have gone so far as to implement CRISPR-Cas9 on embryos to select for protection against HIV. Researchers at the National Institutes of Health worry that germline genome editing is not well-researched and, as a result, may pose a safety concern for testing on embryos; others have moral or religious objections against human embryo testing, and, as a result, federal funds are currently not being used for any gene-editing research on embryos. However, many countries are continuing to fund CRISPR research on viable and non-viable embryos to try and gain a better understanding of how germline editing affects future generations. In general, bioethicists and researchers currently agree that studies testing human genome editing for reproductive purposes should be avoided.

(10). Although there remains a lot of research to be done, the CRISPR-Cas9 mediated genome editing technology is a promising tool that has the potential to increase crop diversity, control gene expression, and even treat genetic disorders. Due to its increased specificity and versatility, CRISPR-Cas9 is quickly becoming a popular system among researchers. It is hoped that advances in technology may lead to a future where scientists can successfully treat genetic diseases and eliminate life-threatening viruses altogether.

question.text: Each of the following CRISPR-Cas9 mediated genome editing technologies has the possibility for each of the below EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, consider the fact that the stem asks for information related to the potential, and thus the future, uses of CRISPR-Cas9. It is likely that a paragraph discussing prospective developments in genome editing technology will be found toward the end of the passage. Indeed, the final paragraph of the passage discusses the future potential of CRISPR-Cas9 mediated genome editing technology. This tells us that CRISPR-Cas9 mediated genome editing technology has the potential to put an end to life-threatening viruses, control gene expression, and increase crop diversity.  It reads: “Although there remains a lot of research to be done, the CRISPR-Cas9 mediated genome editing technology is a promising tool that has the potential to increase crop diversity , control gene expression , and even treat genetic disorders. Due to its increased specificity and versatility, CRISPR-Cas9 is quickly becoming a popular system among researchers. It is hoped that advances in technology may lead to a future where scientists can successfully treat genetic diseases and eliminate life-threatening viruses altogether.” The only answer choice NOT listed here is to eradicate genetic diseases . Paragraph 10 states that CRISPR-Cas9 could be used to treat genetic diseases but does not mention that it will have the capacity to put an end to them altogether. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Destroy hazardous viruses – is incorrect because, according to paragraph 10, CRISPR-Cas9 could be used for this in the future: “Due to its increased specificity and versatility, CRISPR-Cas9 is quickly becoming a popular system among researchers. It is hoped that advances in technology may lead to a future where scientists can successfully treat genetic diseases and eliminate life-threatening viruses altogether.” Option B. Manage gene activity – is incorrect because, according to paragraph 10, CRISPR-Cas9 could be used for this in the future: “…the CRISPR-Cas9 mediated genome editing technology is a promising tool that has the potential to increase crop diversity, control gene expression, and even treat genetic disorders.” Option C. Augment crop diversity – is incorrect because, according to paragraph 10, CRISPR-Cas9 could be used for this in the future: “…the CRISPR-Cas9 mediated genome editing technology is a promising tool that has the potential to increase crop diversity, control gene expression, and even treat genetic disorders.”
