question.text: What is the primary purpose of CasOT?

options.label: A.
options.text: It cleaves parts of target DNA sequences

options.label: B.
options.text: It remains bound to the DNA sequence

options.label: C.
options.text: It searches for potential off-target sites

correct_answer_text: It searches for potential off-target sites

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should scan the passage for the initial or only mention of CasOT. It can be presumed that a description of its primary purpose will follow its introduction in the text. CasOT is only brought up in paragraph 6: “…in 2014, scientists developed a searching tool known as CasOT, which locates possible off-target sites throughout the genome, and this has helped to reduce the number of off-target mutations.” This tells us that the purpose of CasOT is to locate potential off-target sites in the genome. Therefore, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. It cleaves parts of target DNA sequences – is incorrect because in paragraph 6, the author says that CasOT “locates possible off-target sites throughout the genome,” not cleaves parts of the target DNA sequences. This is done by the Cas9 enzyme. Option B. It remains bound to the DNA sequence – is incorrect because in paragraph 6, the author says that CasOT “locates possible off-target sites throughout the genome,” not that it remains bound to the DNA sequence. This better describes dCas9. Option D. It locates potential PAM sequences – is incorrect because in paragraph 6, the author says that CasOT “locates possible off-target sites throughout the genome,” not that it locates potential PAM sequences.

passage.title: Passage 2
passage.text:
(1). The plastic pollution crisis has escalated to the point where it has now become a global issue. It is estimated that by 2030, the amount of plastic pollution on the planet will double; if this epidemic continues, by 2050, there will be far more plastic than fish in the sea. But how did this crisis begin?

(2). Plastic is synthesized by assembling long-chain molecules from single repetitive units known as monomers; with the addition of heat, pressure, and catalysts, chemical reactions are performed to link such monomers together. Typically, the monomers used in plastic synthesis are derived from fossil fuels (crude oil and natural gas). Polyethylene terephthalate (or PET) is a commonly used polymer that is found in the manufacturing of bottles and clothing, while Bakelite, or polyoxybenzylmethylenglycolanhydride, was the first synthetic plastic produced in 1907.

(3). Global plastic production started to take off rapidly in the 1950s. While production was estimated to have been only 2 million tonnes annually in 1950, by 2015, plastic production was recorded to be 381 million tonnes per year, an increase of approximately 200-fold. By now, the world has already produced 78 billion tonnes of plastic.

(4). After the end of the Second World War, materials developed for use during combat such as polyethylene (a product originally used to insulate radar cables), were adapted for post-war applications, and became widely used as consumer plastics. Prior to the mid-20th century, consumer goods were made from traditional materials like wood, glass, and metal. However, techniques such as injection molding allowed plastic to be produced more efficiently than these materials and in greater quantities, lowering their overall cost and making them more accessible to the growing middle class of the post-war era. The economic boom that followed the war further led to the growth of consumer culture and plastics rapidly became the material of choice for a wide range of goods, from kitchen utensils to children’s toys. Thus, plastics transformed everyday life, becoming integral to society as we know it today.

(5). The appetite for plastic seems to stem from its irresistibly attractive qualities, such as its lightweight nature, flexibility, versatility, strength, water-resistant capacity, and most of all, its relatively cheap cost; however, people’s insatiable desire for the material has resulted in the over-consumption of plastic goods. Although its durability and slow-to-degrade nature allowed plastics to be utilized in mass production, the large-scale use of plastic has come at a high cost. Over time, plastic has lingered as waste, waste that has slowly suffocated wildlife, adversely impacted human health, and polluted the environment.

(6). Improperly discarded plastic can impact our wildlife via three crucial routes, the first being “entanglement,” which is the entrapping, encircling, or constricting of marine animals by plastic debris. In most cases, wildlife becomes entangled in plastic ropes and netting and/or discarded fishing gear, while entanglement due to plastic packaging has also been documented.

(7). The second route is via the “ingestion” of plastic, which can occur intentionally due to an animal mistaking plastic for food, or unintentionally and indirectly, for instance, via the ingestion of prey species that contain plastic. Additionally, tiny pieces of plastic such as plastic fibers may accidentally be taken up by filter-feeding oysters or mussels. As we travel upwards on the food chain, ingesting such toxic material becomes increasingly deadly due to bioaccumulation and thus, would pose a huge risk to iconic creatures such as sharks and other predators at the top of our ocean’s food chains. In larger fish, scientists have recorded the presence of cigarette packets, food packaging, and plastic films; in some extreme cases, a rope, hose, flowerpots, and plastic sheeting have been found in sperm whales. Consumption of large volumes of plastic can have varied biological effects, such as decreased stomach capacity, poor appetite, and a misleading sense of satiation. The specific impact of reduced food intake in certain organisms has been carefully investigated and documented by researchers. For instance, it results in a slower metabolic rate and survival in Asian green mussels, reduced reproducibility in copepods, reduced growth and development of langoustine, and decreased energy stores in shore crabs. Other effects include obstruction or perforation of the gut, gastric rupture, ulcerative lesions, and even death. Some of the biochemical responses to plastic ingestion are metabolic disruption, decreased enzyme activity, cellular necrosis, and oxidative stress.

(8). The third crucial route by which plastic debris affects wildlife is through “interaction.” This includes contact with plastic waste through collisions, obstructions, and abrasions. One simple example is fishing gear, which can cause damage to coral reef ecosystems and other marine wildlife upon collision. Plastic debris can also interfere with substrate availability and disrupt light penetration and oxygen exchange.

(9). Research on the exposure and impact of microplastics (plastic particles >4.75 mm in diameter) on human health is ongoing. The smaller the particle size (micro-and nano-range), the greater the concern for human health. Possible routes of exposure to these minuscule particles include consumption through water and marine products, exposure to the skin via cosmetics, or inhalation of particles in the air. Research suggests that, for humans, the danger due to uptake of microplastics through diet is limited; microplastics appear to concentrate within the gut and the digestive tracts of fish, parts not typically consumed by humans. However, plastic fibers have also been detected in honey, beer, and table salt. To date, research only indicates negligible health risks from such exposure, though the mechanisms of microplastic interaction within the body are yet to be discovered, if at all. A study of North Sea fish suggested that plastic does not persist for a long duration within the organism; thus, one hypothesis is that plastic particles may directly exit through the GI tract without any negative impact, which would indeed bring about a wave of relief. However, such results may be met with skepticism and can perhaps only begin to be accepted once such studies are replicated, and findings are deemed reliable. It is hoped that future studies will better characterize the potential risks of microplastics and their impact on human health.

(10). Although the long-term effects of microplastics on human health have not been proven, the consumption of these particles could potentially lead to a host of troubling issues. For instance, microplastics may irritate the lining of the digestive tract and, if able to enter vital organs such as the brain or liver, could disrupt the body’s normal functions. In the long term, the ingestion of microplastics may cause developmental, reproductive, and metabolic disorders. If microplastics were to carry with them dangerous microorganisms from the environment, this could also cause infections within the body. Microplastics may impact the human immune system, resulting in chronic inflammation or immune-related diseases. Additionally, it has been suggested that microplastics can cause cancer because certain additives in plastic are known to be carcinogenic, including a compound known as “styrene.” Repeated exposure to carcinogenic materials, such as through the repeated consumption of microplastics containing these particles, could feasibly increase one’s risk of the disease.

(11). Plastic waste is commonly handled in one of three ways: through recycling, incineration (the burning of any given material), or disposal in landfills. A meta-study analyzed the impact of each method across factors, such as its global warming potential (GWP) and its total energy use (TEU). Across nearly all studies examined, recycling appears to be the most suitable option. Still, a few caveats must be noted. For instance, plastics can usually only be recycled once or twice; following this, they either end up in a landfill or must be incinerated. As such, recycling seems only to delay, rather than prevent, incineration and disposal. Also, recycling may not be the most economically favorable choice because recycled material is not necessarily a one-for-one displacement of primary plastic production. In other words, each tonne of recycled material does not prevent one tonne of primary material from being produced. This is due to the nature of the recycling process, which often results in products of lower economic value termed as “downcycling.”

(12). In the 1980s and prior, plastic was largely discarded, while recycling and incineration were negligible. Incineration and recycling rates began to increase from 1980 and 1990, respectively, by approximately 0.7% per year; by 2015, about half of the global plastic waste was discarded, a quarter incinerated, and another quarter recycled. Extrapolating historical trends to 2050, incineration rates are predicted to increase to 50%, recycling to 44%, and discarded waste is estimated to decline to a mere 6%.

(13). Although the potential increase in the recycling trend is to our advantage, the same cannot be said for the predicted incline in incineration rates. The burning of plastic can release toxic chemicals, such as hydrochloric acid, sulfur dioxide, heavy metals, and other carcinogens that can have adverse effects on the human body, but the horror does not stop there. Incineration of plastic has several environmental impacts as well – these include the production of greenhouse gases, such as carbon dioxide (CO2), which contributes to climate change, the incomplete combustion of Polyethylene (PE), Polypropylene (PP), and Polystyrene (PS), which can release toxic gases such as carbon monoxide (CO). Additionally, polyvinyl chloride (PVC) can produce dioxins, which are persistent organic pollutants (POPs). Therefore, to avoid such detrimental effects, it is necessary to prevent the open or uncontrolled incineration of plastics.

(14). High-income countries have invested in the regulation of waste management and incinerator sites by monitoring the emissions and potential leakages to the environment. Modern incinerators have been designed to combat the issue of dioxins and other toxic emissions by ensuring efficient combustion, selective catalytic reduction, end-of-pipe treatment, and the addition of appropriate inhibitors. A testament to the success of such technologies has been evidenced by a study conducted in Belgium where no increase was recorded in the dioxin-serum levels of those working in municipal incinerator facilities compared to the high exposure rates they would have experienced if such methods were not in place. However, in low-to-middle income countries where such incinerator technologies are vastly absent and environmental regulations are laxer, the open burning of municipal waste is a continual occurrence. The adoption of modern, efficient, low-risk technologies is required on the global scale to convert incineration into a universally safe solution for plastic waste management.

(15). Once plastic enters our oceans via coastlines, tides, rivers, and marine waters, its accumulation and dispersion patterns are determined by oceanic surface currents and winds. The buoyant nature of plastic allows it to float on oceanic surfaces, and because of being carried by the wind, plastics tend to agglomerate in oceanic gyres, with the greatest concentration at the center of ocean basins. Basins located in the Northern Hemisphere were recorded to have the greatest concentration of plastics, a predictable outcome because most of the world’s population resides within the Northern Hemisphere. Although the quantity of plastic clustered in Southern oceans was relatively lesser than in the Northern oceans, the amount was of the same order of magnitude as the Northern; this was surprising as there is a lack of coastal populations and plastic inputs in the Southern Hemisphere. This unexpected finding suggests that plastic pollution can be transported between oceanic gyres and basins to a significantly greater degree than once hypothesized.

(16). So, what is the solution? A plethora of ideas has been suggested, with many underways. But, the question remains, will all, or any, of them, be successful? As Tom Downdall, the owner of Transformative Change Consulting, very aptly stated in response to the popular focus on recyclability and recycling: “Solving the plastic pollution crisis requires focus on another ‘R’—Responsibility.” If everyone, from multi-million-dollar companies to singular individuals, were to assume the responsibility and become intentional in their efforts to combat the plastic pollution crisis, then perhaps there might still be hope.

question.text: Each of the following types of plastic debris have been discovered inside larger marine life EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should locate the paragraph or paragraphs in the passage discussing the impact of plastic waste on animal life. If we note that this topic is discussed in paragraphs 6-9, we can then scan each of these sections to determine which mentions the effects of plastic waste on large fish. This is discussed in paragraph 7: “As we travel upwards on the food chain, ingesting such toxic material becomes increasingly deadly due to bioaccumulation and thus, would pose a huge risk to iconic creatures such as sharks and other predators at the top of our ocean’s food chains. In larger fish, scientists have recorded the presence of cigarette packets, food packaging , and plastic films; in some extreme cases, a rope, hose, flowerpots, and plastic sheeting have been found in sperm whales. This tells us that food packaging, plastic sheeting, and hoses have been found in larger marine life. The only option choice NOT mentioned is plastic fibers . According to paragraph 7, micro-plastics are likely to be ingested by filter-feeding organisms, not large fish. Therefore, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Food packaging – is incorrect because paragraph 7 does mention that food packaging has been found inside of larger marine life. “In larger fish, scientists have recorded the presence of cigarette packets, food packaging, and plastic films…” Option B. Plastic sheeting – is incorrect because paragraph 7 does mention that plastic sheeting has been found inside larger marine life, specifically sperm whales: “In larger fish, scientists have recorded the presence of cigarette packets, food packaging, and plastic films; in some extreme cases, a rope, hose, flowerpots, and plastic sheeting have been found in sperm whales.” Option D. Hoses – is incorrect because paragraph 7 does mention that hoses have been found inside larger marine life, specifically sperm whales: “In larger fish, scientists have recorded the presence of cigarette packets, food packaging, and plastic films; in some extreme cases, a rope, hose, flowerpots, and plastic sheeting have been found in sperm whales.”

passage.title: Passage 2
passage.text:
(1). The plastic pollution crisis has escalated to the point where it has now become a global issue. It is estimated that by 2030, the amount of plastic pollution on the planet will double; if this epidemic continues, by 2050, there will be far more plastic than fish in the sea. But how did this crisis begin?

(2). Plastic is synthesized by assembling long-chain molecules from single repetitive units known as monomers; with the addition of heat, pressure, and catalysts, chemical reactions are performed to link such monomers together. Typically, the monomers used in plastic synthesis are derived from fossil fuels (crude oil and natural gas). Polyethylene terephthalate (or PET) is a commonly used polymer that is found in the manufacturing of bottles and clothing, while Bakelite, or polyoxybenzylmethylenglycolanhydride, was the first synthetic plastic produced in 1907.

(3). Global plastic production started to take off rapidly in the 1950s. While production was estimated to have been only 2 million tonnes annually in 1950, by 2015, plastic production was recorded to be 381 million tonnes per year, an increase of approximately 200-fold. By now, the world has already produced 78 billion tonnes of plastic.

(4). After the end of the Second World War, materials developed for use during combat such as polyethylene (a product originally used to insulate radar cables), were adapted for post-war applications, and became widely used as consumer plastics. Prior to the mid-20th century, consumer goods were made from traditional materials like wood, glass, and metal. However, techniques such as injection molding allowed plastic to be produced more efficiently than these materials and in greater quantities, lowering their overall cost and making them more accessible to the growing middle class of the post-war era. The economic boom that followed the war further led to the growth of consumer culture and plastics rapidly became the material of choice for a wide range of goods, from kitchen utensils to children’s toys. Thus, plastics transformed everyday life, becoming integral to society as we know it today.

(5). The appetite for plastic seems to stem from its irresistibly attractive qualities, such as its lightweight nature, flexibility, versatility, strength, water-resistant capacity, and most of all, its relatively cheap cost; however, people’s insatiable desire for the material has resulted in the over-consumption of plastic goods. Although its durability and slow-to-degrade nature allowed plastics to be utilized in mass production, the large-scale use of plastic has come at a high cost. Over time, plastic has lingered as waste, waste that has slowly suffocated wildlife, adversely impacted human health, and polluted the environment.

(6). Improperly discarded plastic can impact our wildlife via three crucial routes, the first being “entanglement,” which is the entrapping, encircling, or constricting of marine animals by plastic debris. In most cases, wildlife becomes entangled in plastic ropes and netting and/or discarded fishing gear, while entanglement due to plastic packaging has also been documented.

(7). The second route is via the “ingestion” of plastic, which can occur intentionally due to an animal mistaking plastic for food, or unintentionally and indirectly, for instance, via the ingestion of prey species that contain plastic. Additionally, tiny pieces of plastic such as plastic fibers may accidentally be taken up by filter-feeding oysters or mussels. As we travel upwards on the food chain, ingesting such toxic material becomes increasingly deadly due to bioaccumulation and thus, would pose a huge risk to iconic creatures such as sharks and other predators at the top of our ocean’s food chains. In larger fish, scientists have recorded the presence of cigarette packets, food packaging, and plastic films; in some extreme cases, a rope, hose, flowerpots, and plastic sheeting have been found in sperm whales. Consumption of large volumes of plastic can have varied biological effects, such as decreased stomach capacity, poor appetite, and a misleading sense of satiation. The specific impact of reduced food intake in certain organisms has been carefully investigated and documented by researchers. For instance, it results in a slower metabolic rate and survival in Asian green mussels, reduced reproducibility in copepods, reduced growth and development of langoustine, and decreased energy stores in shore crabs. Other effects include obstruction or perforation of the gut, gastric rupture, ulcerative lesions, and even death. Some of the biochemical responses to plastic ingestion are metabolic disruption, decreased enzyme activity, cellular necrosis, and oxidative stress.

(8). The third crucial route by which plastic debris affects wildlife is through “interaction.” This includes contact with plastic waste through collisions, obstructions, and abrasions. One simple example is fishing gear, which can cause damage to coral reef ecosystems and other marine wildlife upon collision. Plastic debris can also interfere with substrate availability and disrupt light penetration and oxygen exchange.

(9). Research on the exposure and impact of microplastics (plastic particles >4.75 mm in diameter) on human health is ongoing. The smaller the particle size (micro-and nano-range), the greater the concern for human health. Possible routes of exposure to these minuscule particles include consumption through water and marine products, exposure to the skin via cosmetics, or inhalation of particles in the air. Research suggests that, for humans, the danger due to uptake of microplastics through diet is limited; microplastics appear to concentrate within the gut and the digestive tracts of fish, parts not typically consumed by humans. However, plastic fibers have also been detected in honey, beer, and table salt. To date, research only indicates negligible health risks from such exposure, though the mechanisms of microplastic interaction within the body are yet to be discovered, if at all. A study of North Sea fish suggested that plastic does not persist for a long duration within the organism; thus, one hypothesis is that plastic particles may directly exit through the GI tract without any negative impact, which would indeed bring about a wave of relief. However, such results may be met with skepticism and can perhaps only begin to be accepted once such studies are replicated, and findings are deemed reliable. It is hoped that future studies will better characterize the potential risks of microplastics and their impact on human health.

(10). Although the long-term effects of microplastics on human health have not been proven, the consumption of these particles could potentially lead to a host of troubling issues. For instance, microplastics may irritate the lining of the digestive tract and, if able to enter vital organs such as the brain or liver, could disrupt the body’s normal functions. In the long term, the ingestion of microplastics may cause developmental, reproductive, and metabolic disorders. If microplastics were to carry with them dangerous microorganisms from the environment, this could also cause infections within the body. Microplastics may impact the human immune system, resulting in chronic inflammation or immune-related diseases. Additionally, it has been suggested that microplastics can cause cancer because certain additives in plastic are known to be carcinogenic, including a compound known as “styrene.” Repeated exposure to carcinogenic materials, such as through the repeated consumption of microplastics containing these particles, could feasibly increase one’s risk of the disease.

(11). Plastic waste is commonly handled in one of three ways: through recycling, incineration (the burning of any given material), or disposal in landfills. A meta-study analyzed the impact of each method across factors, such as its global warming potential (GWP) and its total energy use (TEU). Across nearly all studies examined, recycling appears to be the most suitable option. Still, a few caveats must be noted. For instance, plastics can usually only be recycled once or twice; following this, they either end up in a landfill or must be incinerated. As such, recycling seems only to delay, rather than prevent, incineration and disposal. Also, recycling may not be the most economically favorable choice because recycled material is not necessarily a one-for-one displacement of primary plastic production. In other words, each tonne of recycled material does not prevent one tonne of primary material from being produced. This is due to the nature of the recycling process, which often results in products of lower economic value termed as “downcycling.”

(12). In the 1980s and prior, plastic was largely discarded, while recycling and incineration were negligible. Incineration and recycling rates began to increase from 1980 and 1990, respectively, by approximately 0.7% per year; by 2015, about half of the global plastic waste was discarded, a quarter incinerated, and another quarter recycled. Extrapolating historical trends to 2050, incineration rates are predicted to increase to 50%, recycling to 44%, and discarded waste is estimated to decline to a mere 6%.

(13). Although the potential increase in the recycling trend is to our advantage, the same cannot be said for the predicted incline in incineration rates. The burning of plastic can release toxic chemicals, such as hydrochloric acid, sulfur dioxide, heavy metals, and other carcinogens that can have adverse effects on the human body, but the horror does not stop there. Incineration of plastic has several environmental impacts as well – these include the production of greenhouse gases, such as carbon dioxide (CO2), which contributes to climate change, the incomplete combustion of Polyethylene (PE), Polypropylene (PP), and Polystyrene (PS), which can release toxic gases such as carbon monoxide (CO). Additionally, polyvinyl chloride (PVC) can produce dioxins, which are persistent organic pollutants (POPs). Therefore, to avoid such detrimental effects, it is necessary to prevent the open or uncontrolled incineration of plastics.

(14). High-income countries have invested in the regulation of waste management and incinerator sites by monitoring the emissions and potential leakages to the environment. Modern incinerators have been designed to combat the issue of dioxins and other toxic emissions by ensuring efficient combustion, selective catalytic reduction, end-of-pipe treatment, and the addition of appropriate inhibitors. A testament to the success of such technologies has been evidenced by a study conducted in Belgium where no increase was recorded in the dioxin-serum levels of those working in municipal incinerator facilities compared to the high exposure rates they would have experienced if such methods were not in place. However, in low-to-middle income countries where such incinerator technologies are vastly absent and environmental regulations are laxer, the open burning of municipal waste is a continual occurrence. The adoption of modern, efficient, low-risk technologies is required on the global scale to convert incineration into a universally safe solution for plastic waste management.

(15). Once plastic enters our oceans via coastlines, tides, rivers, and marine waters, its accumulation and dispersion patterns are determined by oceanic surface currents and winds. The buoyant nature of plastic allows it to float on oceanic surfaces, and because of being carried by the wind, plastics tend to agglomerate in oceanic gyres, with the greatest concentration at the center of ocean basins. Basins located in the Northern Hemisphere were recorded to have the greatest concentration of plastics, a predictable outcome because most of the world’s population resides within the Northern Hemisphere. Although the quantity of plastic clustered in Southern oceans was relatively lesser than in the Northern oceans, the amount was of the same order of magnitude as the Northern; this was surprising as there is a lack of coastal populations and plastic inputs in the Southern Hemisphere. This unexpected finding suggests that plastic pollution can be transported between oceanic gyres and basins to a significantly greater degree than once hypothesized.

(16). So, what is the solution? A plethora of ideas has been suggested, with many underways. But, the question remains, will all, or any, of them, be successful? As Tom Downdall, the owner of Transformative Change Consulting, very aptly stated in response to the popular focus on recyclability and recycling: “Solving the plastic pollution crisis requires focus on another ‘R’—Responsibility.” If everyone, from multi-million-dollar companies to singular individuals, were to assume the responsibility and become intentional in their efforts to combat the plastic pollution crisis, then perhaps there might still be hope.

question.text: What did the study of North Sea fish mentioned in the passage suggest?

options.label: A.
options.text: Microplastics collect in the digestive tracts of fish

options.label: B.
options.text: Plastic does not remain in organisms for a sustained amount of time

options.label: D.
options.text: Plastic consumption interferes with langoustines’ growth

correct_answer_text: Plastic does not remain in organisms for a sustained amount of time

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should search the passage for the paragraphs discussing the effects of plastic waste on sea life. While paragraphs 6-9 discuss this, the North Sea fish study is only mentioned in paragraph 9, which reads: “A study of North Sea fish suggested that plastic does not persist for a long duration within the organism; thus, one hypothesis is that plastic particles may directly exit through the GI tract without any negative impact, which would indeed bring about a wave of relief.” This tells us that the North Sea study suggests plastic does not persist for very long in organisms. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Microplastics collect in the digestive tracts of fish – is incorrect because this is also mentioned in paragraph 9 but is not credited to the North Sea study: “Microplastics appear to concentrate within the gut and the digestive tracts of fish, parts not typically consumed by humans.” Option C. Plastic debris hinders substrate availability – is incorrect because this is mentioned in paragraph 8 but is not credited to the North Sea study: “ Plastic debris can also interfere with substrate availability and disrupt light penetration and oxygen exchange.” Option D. Plastic consumption interferes with langoustines’ growth – is incorrect because this is mentioned to be a result of plastic being ingested by sea life in paragraph 7 but is not credited to the North Sea study. “For instance, it results in a slower metabolic rate and survival in Asian green mussels, reduced reproducibility in copepods, reduced growth and development of langoustine, and decreased energy stores in shore crabs . ”

question.text: Which of the following influences the accumulation and dispersion pattern of plastic in the ocean?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should locate the paragraph or paragraphs discussing how plastic accumulates in the ocean. This is discussed most in-depth in paragraph 15: “Once plastic enters our oceans via coastlines, tides, rivers, and marine waters, its accumulation and dispersion patterns are determined by oceanic surface currents and winds. The buoyant nature of plastic allows it to float on oceanic surfaces, and because of being carried by the wind, plastics tend to agglomerate in oceanic gyres, with the greatest concentration at the center of ocean basins.” This tells us that once plastic enters the ocean, its accumulation and dispersion pattern is determined by oceanic surface currents. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. The plastic’s buoyant qualities – is incorrect because paragraph 15 states that the buoyant nature of plastic allows it to float on ocean surfaces, but it is oceanic surface currents that determine its accumulation and dispersion patterns. “Once plastic enters our oceans via coastlines, tides, rivers, and marine waters, its accumulation and dispersion patterns are determined by oceanic surface currents and winds.” Option B. The currents formed in gyres – is incorrect because paragraph 15 states that plastic amasses in ocean gyres, but it is oceanic surface currents that determine its accumulation and dispersion patterns. “Once plastic enters our oceans via coastlines, tides, rivers, and marine waters, its accumulation and dispersion patterns are determined by oceanic surface currents and winds. The buoyant nature of plastic allows it to float on oceanic surfaces, and because of being carried by the wind, plastics tend to agglomerate in oceanic gyres, with the greatest concentration at the center of ocean basins.” Option C. Tidal currents – is incorrect because paragraph 15 states that oceanic surface currents, not tidal currents, determine the accumulation and dispersion patterns of plastic. “Once plastic enters our oceans via coastlines, tides, rivers, and marine waters, its accumulation and dispersion patterns are determined by oceanic surface currents and winds.”

Plastic is synthesized by assembling long-chain molecules from single repetitive units known as monomers; with the addition of heat, pressure, and catalysts, chemical reactions are performed to link such monomers together. Typically, the monomers used in plastic synthesis are derived from fossil fuels (crude oil and natural gas). Polyethylene terephthalate (or PET) is a commonly used polymer that is found in the manufacturing of bottles and clothing, while Bakelite, or polyoxybenzylmethylenglycolanhydride, was the first synthetic plastic produced in 1907.

(3). Global plastic production started to take off rapidly in the 1950s. While production was estimated to have been only 2 million tonnes annually in 1950, by 2015, plastic production was recorded to be 381 million tonnes per year, an increase of approximately 200-fold. By now, the world has already produced 78 billion tonnes of plastic.

(4). After the end of the Second World War, materials developed for use during combat such as polyethylene (a product originally used to insulate radar cables), were adapted for post-war applications, and became widely used as consumer plastics. Prior to the mid-20th century, consumer goods were made from traditional materials like wood, glass, and metal. However, techniques such as injection molding allowed plastic to be produced more efficiently than these materials and in greater quantities, lowering their overall cost and making them more accessible to the growing middle class of the post-war era. The economic boom that followed the war further led to the growth of consumer culture and plastics rapidly became the material of choice for a wide range of goods, from kitchen utensils to children’s toys. Thus, plastics transformed everyday life, becoming integral to society as we know it today.

(5). The appetite for plastic seems to stem from its irresistibly attractive qualities, such as its lightweight nature, flexibility, versatility, strength, water-resistant capacity, and most of all, its relatively cheap cost; however, people’s insatiable desire for the material has resulted in the over-consumption of plastic goods. Although its durability and slow-to-degrade nature allowed plastics to be utilized in mass production, the large-scale use of plastic has come at a high cost. Over time, plastic has lingered as waste, waste that has slowly suffocated wildlife, adversely impacted human health, and polluted the environment.

(6). Improperly discarded plastic can impact our wildlife via three crucial routes, the first being “entanglement,” which is the entrapping, encircling, or constricting of marine animals by plastic debris. In most cases, wildlife becomes entangled in plastic ropes and netting and/or discarded fishing gear, while entanglement due to plastic packaging has also been documented.

(7). The second route is via the “ingestion” of plastic, which can occur intentionally due to an animal mistaking plastic for food, or unintentionally and indirectly, for instance, via the ingestion of prey species that contain plastic. Additionally, tiny pieces of plastic such as plastic fibers may accidentally be taken up by filter-feeding oysters or mussels. As we travel upwards on the food chain, ingesting such toxic material becomes increasingly deadly due to bioaccumulation and thus, would pose a huge risk to iconic creatures such as sharks and other predators at the top of our ocean’s food chains. In larger fish, scientists have recorded the presence of cigarette packets, food packaging, and plastic films; in some extreme cases, a rope, hose, flowerpots, and plastic sheeting have been found in sperm whales. Consumption of large volumes of plastic can have varied biological effects, such as decreased stomach capacity, poor appetite, and a misleading sense of satiation. The specific impact of reduced food intake in certain organisms has been carefully investigated and documented by researchers. For instance, it results in a slower metabolic rate and survival in Asian green mussels, reduced reproducibility in copepods, reduced growth and development of langoustine, and decreased energy stores in shore crabs. Other effects include obstruction or perforation of the gut, gastric rupture, ulcerative lesions, and even death. Some of the biochemical responses to plastic ingestion are metabolic disruption, decreased enzyme activity, cellular necrosis, and oxidative stress.

(8). The third crucial route by which plastic debris affects wildlife is through “interaction.” This includes contact with plastic waste through collisions, obstructions, and abrasions. One simple example is fishing gear, which can cause damage to coral reef ecosystems and other marine wildlife upon collision. Plastic debris can also interfere with substrate availability and disrupt light penetration and oxygen exchange.

(9). Research on the exposure and impact of microplastics (plastic particles >4.75 mm in diameter) on human health is ongoing. The smaller the particle size (micro-and nano-range), the greater the concern for human health. Possible routes of exposure to these minuscule particles include consumption through water and marine products, exposure to the skin via cosmetics, or inhalation of particles in the air. Research suggests that, for humans, the danger due to uptake of microplastics through diet is limited; microplastics appear to concentrate within the gut and the digestive tracts of fish, parts not typically consumed by humans. However, plastic fibers have also been detected in honey, beer, and table salt. To date, research only indicates negligible health risks from such exposure, though the mechanisms of microplastic interaction within the body are yet to be discovered, if at all. A study of North Sea fish suggested that plastic does not persist for a long duration within the organism; thus, one hypothesis is that plastic particles may directly exit through the GI tract without any negative impact, which would indeed bring about a wave of relief. However, such results may be met with skepticism and can perhaps only begin to be accepted once such studies are replicated, and findings are deemed reliable. It is hoped that future studies will better characterize the potential risks of microplastics and their impact on human health.

(10). Although the long-term effects of microplastics on human health have not been proven, the consumption of these particles could potentially lead to a host of troubling issues. For instance, microplastics may irritate the lining of the digestive tract and, if able to enter vital organs such as the brain or liver, could disrupt the body’s normal functions. In the long term, the ingestion of microplastics may cause developmental, reproductive, and metabolic disorders. If microplastics were to carry with them dangerous microorganisms from the environment, this could also cause infections within the body. Microplastics may impact the human immune system, resulting in chronic inflammation or immune-related diseases. Additionally, it has been suggested that microplastics can cause cancer because certain additives in plastic are known to be carcinogenic, including a compound known as “styrene.” Repeated exposure to carcinogenic materials, such as through the repeated consumption of microplastics containing these particles, could feasibly increase one’s risk of the disease.

(11). Plastic waste is commonly handled in one of three ways: through recycling, incineration (the burning of any given material), or disposal in landfills. A meta-study analyzed the impact of each method across factors, such as its global warming potential (GWP) and its total energy use (TEU). Across nearly all studies examined, recycling appears to be the most suitable option. Still, a few caveats must be noted. For instance, plastics can usually only be recycled once or twice; following this, they either end up in a landfill or must be incinerated. As such, recycling seems only to delay, rather than prevent, incineration and disposal. Also, recycling may not be the most economically favorable choice because recycled material is not necessarily a one-for-one displacement of primary plastic production. In other words, each tonne of recycled material does not prevent one tonne of primary material from being produced. This is due to the nature of the recycling process, which often results in products of lower economic value termed as “downcycling.”

(12). In the 1980s and prior, plastic was largely discarded, while recycling and incineration were negligible. Incineration and recycling rates began to increase from 1980 and 1990, respectively, by approximately 0.7% per year; by 2015, about half of the global plastic waste was discarded, a quarter incinerated, and another quarter recycled. Extrapolating historical trends to 2050, incineration rates are predicted to increase to 50%, recycling to 44%, and discarded waste is estimated to decline to a mere 6%.

(13). Although the potential increase in the recycling trend is to our advantage, the same cannot be said for the predicted incline in incineration rates. The burning of plastic can release toxic chemicals, such as hydrochloric acid, sulfur dioxide, heavy metals, and other carcinogens that can have adverse effects on the human body, but the horror does not stop there. Incineration of plastic has several environmental impacts as well – these include the production of greenhouse gases, such as carbon dioxide (CO2), which contributes to climate change, the incomplete combustion of Polyethylene (PE), Polypropylene (PP), and Polystyrene (PS), which can release toxic gases such as carbon monoxide (CO). Additionally, polyvinyl chloride (PVC) can produce dioxins, which are persistent organic pollutants (POPs). Therefore, to avoid such detrimental effects, it is necessary to prevent the open or uncontrolled incineration of plastics.

(14). High-income countries have invested in the regulation of waste management and incinerator sites by monitoring the emissions and potential leakages to the environment. Modern incinerators have been designed to combat the issue of dioxins and other toxic emissions by ensuring efficient combustion, selective catalytic reduction, end-of-pipe treatment, and the addition of appropriate inhibitors. A testament to the success of such technologies has been evidenced by a study conducted in Belgium where no increase was recorded in the dioxin-serum levels of those working in municipal incinerator facilities compared to the high exposure rates they would have experienced if such methods were not in place. However, in low-to-middle income countries where such incinerator technologies are vastly absent and environmental regulations are laxer, the open burning of municipal waste is a continual occurrence. The adoption of modern, efficient, low-risk technologies is required on the global scale to convert incineration into a universally safe solution for plastic waste management.

(15). Once plastic enters our oceans via coastlines, tides, rivers, and marine waters, its accumulation and dispersion patterns are determined by oceanic surface currents and winds. The buoyant nature of plastic allows it to float on oceanic surfaces, and because of being carried by the wind, plastics tend to agglomerate in oceanic gyres, with the greatest concentration at the center of ocean basins. Basins located in the Northern Hemisphere were recorded to have the greatest concentration of plastics, a predictable outcome because most of the world’s population resides within the Northern Hemisphere. Although the quantity of plastic clustered in Southern oceans was relatively lesser than in the Northern oceans, the amount was of the same order of magnitude as the Northern; this was surprising as there is a lack of coastal populations and plastic inputs in the Southern Hemisphere. This unexpected finding suggests that plastic pollution can be transported between oceanic gyres and basins to a significantly greater degree than once hypothesized.

(16). So, what is the solution? A plethora of ideas has been suggested, with many underways. But, the question remains, will all, or any, of them, be successful? As Tom Downdall, the owner of Transformative Change Consulting, very aptly stated in response to the popular focus on recyclability and recycling: “Solving the plastic pollution crisis requires focus on another ‘R’—Responsibility.” If everyone, from multi-million-dollar companies to singular individuals, were to assume the responsibility and become intentional in their efforts to combat the plastic pollution crisis, then perhaps there might still be hope.

question.text: Present-day incinerators have been created to counter toxic emissions by certifying that each of the following safety protocols are in place EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should search the passage for the paragraph or paragraphs discussing plastic waste incineration. If we note that this is mentioned in paragraphs 11-14, we should then scan each of these paragraphs for the one which references the combatting of toxic emissions created by plastic waste incineration. This is brought up in paragraph 14. The statement below is mentioned by the author in paragraph 14. This tells us that modern incinerators have been designed to combat toxic emissions by ensuring efficient combustion, selective catalytic reduction, end-of-pipe treatment, and the addition of appropriate inhibitors. “High-income countries have invested in the regulation of waste management and incinerator sites by monitoring the emissions and potential leakages to the environment. Modern incinerators have been designed to combat the issue of dioxins and other toxic emissions by ensuring efficient combustion , selective catalytic reduction , end-of-pipe treatment, and the addition of appropriate inhibitors .” The only option choice NOT listed above is open burning . Open burning is considered bad for the environment, according to paragraph 14 which reads: “However, in low-to-middle income countries where such incinerator technologies are vastly absent, and environmental regulations are laxer, the open burning of municipal waste is a continual occurrence.” Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Efficient combustion – is incorrect because this is a safety measure mentioned in paragraph 14: “Modern incinerators have been designed to combat the issue of dioxins and other toxic emissions by ensuring efficient combustion, selective catalytic reduction, end-of-pipe treatment, and the addition of appropriate inhibitors.” Option B. Appropriate inhibitors – is incorrect because this is a safety measure mentioned in paragraph 14: “Modern incinerators have been designed to combat the issue of dioxins and other toxic emissions by ensuring efficient combustion, selective catalytic reduction, end-of-pipe treatment, and the addition of appropriate inhibitors.” Option C. Selective catalytic reduction – is incorrect because this is a safety measure mentioned in paragraph 14: “Modern incinerators have been designed to combat the issue of dioxins and other toxic emissions by ensuring efficient combustion, selective catalytic reduction, end-of-pipe treatment, and the addition of appropriate inhibitors.”

question.text: What was the annual volume of plastic production recorded to be by 2015?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should search the passage for a paragraph that shares the statistics relating to plastic production. Paragraph 3 contains these figures and reads: “Global plastic production started to take off rapidly in the 1950s. While production was estimated to have been only 2 million tonnes annually in 1950, by 2015, plastic production was recorded to be 381 million tonnes per year, an increase of approximately 200-fold. By now, the world has already produced 78 billion tonnes of plastic. “ This tells us that plastic production was recorded to be at 381 million tonnes per year by 2015. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. 2 million tonnes – is incorrect because this was the amount of plastic production per year by 1950, not 2005, according to paragraph 3: “Global plastic production started to take off rapidly in the 1950s. While production was estimated to have been only 2 million tonnes annually in 1950…” Option B. 2.5 million tonnes – is incorrect because paragraph 3 states that plastic production per year by 2015 was 381 million tonnes, not 2.5 million tonnes: “…by 2015, plastic production was recorded to be 381 million tonnes per year…” Option C. 150 million tonnes – is incorrect because paragraph 3 states that plastic production per year by 2015 was 381 million tonnes, not 150 million tonnes: “…by 2015, plastic production was recorded to be 381 million tonnes per year…”

Extrapolating historical trends to 2050, incineration rates are predicted to increase to 50%, recycling to 44%, and discarded waste is estimated to decline to a mere 6%.

(13). Although the potential increase in the recycling trend is to our advantage, the same cannot be said for the predicted incline in incineration rates. The burning of plastic can release toxic chemicals, such as hydrochloric acid, sulfur dioxide, heavy metals, and other carcinogens that can have adverse effects on the human body, but the horror does not stop there. Incineration of plastic has several environmental impacts as well – these include the production of greenhouse gases, such as carbon dioxide (CO2), which contributes to climate change, the incomplete combustion of Polyethylene (PE), Polypropylene (PP), and Polystyrene (PS), which can release toxic gases such as carbon monoxide (CO). Additionally, polyvinyl chloride (PVC) can produce dioxins, which are persistent organic pollutants (POPs). Therefore, to avoid such detrimental effects, it is necessary to prevent the open or uncontrolled incineration of plastics.

(14). High-income countries have invested in the regulation of waste management and incinerator sites by monitoring the emissions and potential leakages to the environment. Modern incinerators have been designed to combat the issue of dioxins and other toxic emissions by ensuring efficient combustion, selective catalytic reduction, end-of-pipe treatment, and the addition of appropriate inhibitors. A testament to the success of such technologies has been evidenced by a study conducted in Belgium where no increase was recorded in the dioxin-serum levels of those working in municipal incinerator facilities compared to the high exposure rates they would have experienced if such methods were not in place. However, in low-to-middle income countries where such incinerator technologies are vastly absent and environmental regulations are laxer, the open burning of municipal waste is a continual occurrence. The adoption of modern, efficient, low-risk technologies is required on the global scale to convert incineration into a universally safe solution for plastic waste management.

(15). Once plastic enters our oceans via coastlines, tides, rivers, and marine waters, its accumulation and dispersion patterns are determined by oceanic surface currents and winds. The buoyant nature of plastic allows it to float on oceanic surfaces, and because of being carried by the wind, plastics tend to agglomerate in oceanic gyres, with the greatest concentration at the center of ocean basins. Basins located in the Northern Hemisphere were recorded to have the greatest concentration of plastics, a predictable outcome because most of the world’s population resides within the Northern Hemisphere. Although the quantity of plastic clustered in Southern oceans was relatively lesser than in the Northern oceans, the amount was of the same order of magnitude as the Northern; this was surprising as there is a lack of coastal populations and plastic inputs in the Southern Hemisphere. This unexpected finding suggests that plastic pollution can be transported between oceanic gyres and basins to a significantly greater degree than once hypothesized.

(16). So, what is the solution? A plethora of ideas has been suggested, with many underways. But, the question remains, will all, or any, of them, be successful? As Tom Downdall, the owner of Transformative Change Consulting, very aptly stated in response to the popular focus on recyclability and recycling: “Solving the plastic pollution crisis requires focus on another ‘R’—Responsibility.” If everyone, from multi-million-dollar companies to singular individuals, were to assume the responsibility and become intentional in their efforts to combat the plastic pollution crisis, then perhaps there might still be hope.

question.text: What method of study was undertaken to examine the effects of recycling, incineration, and landfill disposal across factors such as its GWP and TEU?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should locate the section of the passage discussing the different methods of plastic waste disposal. It can be presumed that a study conducted to analyze the impact of recycling, incineration, and landfill disposal will be mentioned in such a section. Plastic waste disposal is discussed in paragraphs 11-14, with paragraph 11 discussing the study referenced in the question stem: “Plastic waste is commonly handled in one of three ways: through recycling, incineration (the burning of any given material), or disposal in landfills. A meta-study analyzed the impact of each method across factors, such as its global warming potential (GWP) and its total energy use (TEU).” This tells us that a meta-study was undertaken to examine the effects of recycling incineration and landfill disposal across factors such as its GWP and TEU. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. A longitudinal study – is incorrect because this is an observational study in which data is gathered from the same sample repeatedly over an extended amount of time. It can last from a few years to even a decade, depending on the kind of information being gathered. Option B. A mega-study – is incorrect because there is no such thing as a “mega-study” therefore, this was a distractor. Option C. A cross-sectional study – is incorrect because this is an observational study where data is collected to study a population at a single point in time to examine the relationship between variables of interest.

passage.title: Passage 2
passage.text:
(1). The plastic pollution crisis has escalated to the point where it has now become a global issue. It is estimated that by 2030, the amount of plastic pollution on the planet will double; if this epidemic continues, by 2050, there will be far more plastic than fish in the sea. But how did this crisis begin?

(2). Plastic is synthesized by assembling long-chain molecules from single repetitive units known as monomers; with the addition of heat, pressure, and catalysts, chemical reactions are performed to link such monomers together. Typically, the monomers used in plastic synthesis are derived from fossil fuels (crude oil and natural gas). Polyethylene terephthalate (or PET) is a commonly used polymer that is found in the manufacturing of bottles and clothing, while Bakelite, or polyoxybenzylmethylenglycolanhydride, was the first synthetic plastic produced in 1907.

(3). Global plastic production started to take off rapidly in the 1950s. While production was estimated to have been only 2 million tonnes annually in 1950, by 2015, plastic production was recorded to be 381 million tonnes per year, an increase of approximately 200-fold. By now, the world has already produced 78 billion tonnes of plastic.

(4). After the end of the Second World War, materials developed for use during combat such as polyethylene (a product originally used to insulate radar cables), were adapted for post-war applications, and became widely used as consumer plastics. Prior to the mid-20th century, consumer goods were made from traditional materials like wood, glass, and metal. However, techniques such as injection molding allowed plastic to be produced more efficiently than these materials and in greater quantities, lowering their overall cost and making them more accessible to the growing middle class of the post-war era. The economic boom that followed the war further led to the growth of consumer culture and plastics rapidly became the material of choice for a wide range of goods, from kitchen utensils to children’s toys. Thus, plastics transformed everyday life, becoming integral to society as we know it today.

(5). The appetite for plastic seems to stem from its irresistibly attractive qualities, such as its lightweight nature, flexibility, versatility, strength, water-resistant capacity, and most of all, its relatively cheap cost; however, people’s insatiable desire for the material has resulted in the over-consumption of plastic goods. Although its durability and slow-to-degrade nature allowed plastics to be utilized in mass production, the large-scale use of plastic has come at a high cost. Over time, plastic has lingered as waste, waste that has slowly suffocated wildlife, adversely impacted human health, and polluted the environment.

(6). Improperly discarded plastic can impact our wildlife via three crucial routes, the first being “entanglement,” which is the entrapping, encircling, or constricting of marine animals by plastic debris. In most cases, wildlife becomes entangled in plastic ropes and netting and/or discarded fishing gear, while entanglement due to plastic packaging has also been documented.

(7). The second route is via the “ingestion” of plastic, which can occur intentionally due to an animal mistaking plastic for food, or unintentionally and indirectly, for instance, via the ingestion of prey species that contain plastic. Additionally, tiny pieces of plastic such as plastic fibers may accidentally be taken up by filter-feeding oysters or mussels. As we travel upwards on the food chain, ingesting such toxic material becomes increasingly deadly due to bioaccumulation and thus, would pose a huge risk to iconic creatures such as sharks and other predators at the top of our ocean’s food chains. In larger fish, scientists have recorded the presence of cigarette packets, food packaging, and plastic films; in some extreme cases, a rope, hose, flowerpots, and plastic sheeting have been found in sperm whales. Consumption of large volumes of plastic can have varied biological effects, such as decreased stomach capacity, poor appetite, and a misleading sense of satiation. The specific impact of reduced food intake in certain organisms has been carefully investigated and documented by researchers. For instance, it results in a slower metabolic rate and survival in Asian green mussels, reduced reproducibility in copepods, reduced growth and development of langoustine, and decreased energy stores in shore crabs. Other effects include obstruction or perforation of the gut, gastric rupture, ulcerative lesions, and even death. Some of the biochemical responses to plastic ingestion are metabolic disruption, decreased enzyme activity, cellular necrosis, and oxidative stress.

(8). The third crucial route by which plastic debris affects wildlife is through “interaction.” This includes contact with plastic waste through collisions, obstructions, and abrasions. One simple example is fishing gear, which can cause damage to coral reef ecosystems and other marine wildlife upon collision. Plastic debris can also interfere with substrate availability and disrupt light penetration and oxygen exchange.

(9). Research on the exposure and impact of microplastics (plastic particles >4.75 mm in diameter) on human health is ongoing. The smaller the particle size (micro-and nano-range), the greater the concern for human health. Possible routes of exposure to these minuscule particles include consumption through water and marine products, exposure to the skin via cosmetics, or inhalation of particles in the air. Research suggests that, for humans, the danger due to uptake of microplastics through diet is limited; microplastics appear to concentrate within the gut and the digestive tracts of fish, parts not typically consumed by humans. However, plastic fibers have also been detected in honey, beer, and table salt. To date, research only indicates negligible health risks from such exposure, though the mechanisms of microplastic interaction within the body are yet to be discovered, if at all. A study of North Sea fish suggested that plastic does not persist for a long duration within the organism; thus, one hypothesis is that plastic particles may directly exit through the GI tract without any negative impact, which would indeed bring about a wave of relief. However, such results may be met with skepticism and can perhaps only begin to be accepted once such studies are replicated, and findings are deemed reliable. It is hoped that future studies will better characterize the potential risks of microplastics and their impact on human health.

(10). Although the long-term effects of microplastics on human health have not been proven, the consumption of these particles could potentially lead to a host of troubling issues. For instance, microplastics may irritate the lining of the digestive tract and, if able to enter vital organs such as the brain or liver, could disrupt the body’s normal functions. In the long term, the ingestion of microplastics may cause developmental, reproductive, and metabolic disorders. If microplastics were to carry with them dangerous microorganisms from the environment, this could also cause infections within the body. Microplastics may impact the human immune system, resulting in chronic inflammation or immune-related diseases. Additionally, it has been suggested that microplastics can cause cancer because certain additives in plastic are known to be carcinogenic, including a compound known as “styrene.” Repeated exposure to carcinogenic materials, such as through the repeated consumption of microplastics containing these particles, could feasibly increase one’s risk of the disease.

(11). Plastic waste is commonly handled in one of three ways: through recycling, incineration (the burning of any given material), or disposal in landfills. A meta-study analyzed the impact of each method across factors, such as its global warming potential (GWP) and its total energy use (TEU). Across nearly all studies examined, recycling appears to be the most suitable option. Still, a few caveats must be noted. For instance, plastics can usually only be recycled once or twice; following this, they either end up in a landfill or must be incinerated. As such, recycling seems only to delay, rather than prevent, incineration and disposal. Also, recycling may not be the most economically favorable choice because recycled material is not necessarily a one-for-one displacement of primary plastic production. In other words, each tonne of recycled material does not prevent one tonne of primary material from being produced. This is due to the nature of the recycling process, which often results in products of lower economic value termed as “downcycling.”

(12). In the 1980s and prior, plastic was largely discarded, while recycling and incineration were negligible. Incineration and recycling rates began to increase from 1980 and 1990, respectively, by approximately 0.7% per year; by 2015, about half of the global plastic waste was discarded, a quarter incinerated, and another quarter recycled. Extrapolating historical trends to 2050, incineration rates are predicted to increase to 50%, recycling to 44%, and discarded waste is estimated to decline to a mere 6%.

(13). Although the potential increase in the recycling trend is to our advantage, the same cannot be said for the predicted incline in incineration rates. The burning of plastic can release toxic chemicals, such as hydrochloric acid, sulfur dioxide, heavy metals, and other carcinogens that can have adverse effects on the human body, but the horror does not stop there. Incineration of plastic has several environmental impacts as well – these include the production of greenhouse gases, such as carbon dioxide (CO2), which contributes to climate change, the incomplete combustion of Polyethylene (PE), Polypropylene (PP), and Polystyrene (PS), which can release toxic gases such as carbon monoxide (CO). Additionally, polyvinyl chloride (PVC) can produce dioxins, which are persistent organic pollutants (POPs). Therefore, to avoid such detrimental effects, it is necessary to prevent the open or uncontrolled incineration of plastics.

(14). High-income countries have invested in the regulation of waste management and incinerator sites by monitoring the emissions and potential leakages to the environment. Modern incinerators have been designed to combat the issue of dioxins and other toxic emissions by ensuring efficient combustion, selective catalytic reduction, end-of-pipe treatment, and the addition of appropriate inhibitors. A testament to the success of such technologies has been evidenced by a study conducted in Belgium where no increase was recorded in the dioxin-serum levels of those working in municipal incinerator facilities compared to the high exposure rates they would have experienced if such methods were not in place. However, in low-to-middle income countries where such incinerator technologies are vastly absent and environmental regulations are laxer, the open burning of municipal waste is a continual occurrence. The adoption of modern, efficient, low-risk technologies is required on the global scale to convert incineration into a universally safe solution for plastic waste management.

(15). Once plastic enters our oceans via coastlines, tides, rivers, and marine waters, its accumulation and dispersion patterns are determined by oceanic surface currents and winds. The buoyant nature of plastic allows it to float on oceanic surfaces, and because of being carried by the wind, plastics tend to agglomerate in oceanic gyres, with the greatest concentration at the center of ocean basins. Basins located in the Northern Hemisphere were recorded to have the greatest concentration of plastics, a predictable outcome because most of the world’s population resides within the Northern Hemisphere. Although the quantity of plastic clustered in Southern oceans was relatively lesser than in the Northern oceans, the amount was of the same order of magnitude as the Northern; this was surprising as there is a lack of coastal populations and plastic inputs in the Southern Hemisphere. This unexpected finding suggests that plastic pollution can be transported between oceanic gyres and basins to a significantly greater degree than once hypothesized.

(16). So, what is the solution? A plethora of ideas has been suggested, with many underways. But, the question remains, will all, or any, of them, be successful? As Tom Downdall, the owner of Transformative Change Consulting, very aptly stated in response to the popular focus on recyclability and recycling: “Solving the plastic pollution crisis requires focus on another ‘R’—Responsibility.” If everyone, from multi-million-dollar companies to singular individuals, were to assume the responsibility and become intentional in their efforts to combat the plastic pollution crisis, then perhaps there might still be hope.

question.text: Which of the following represents the predicted increase in the amount of plastic waste incineration between 2015 to 2050?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should locate the section of the passage discussing the different methods of plastic waste disposal. It can be presumed that incineration rates will be mentioned in such a section. Plastic waste disposal is discussed in paragraphs 11-14, with paragraph 12 discussing increasing incineration rates: “…by 2015, about half of the global plastic waste was discarded, a quarter incinerated, and another quarter recycled. Extrapolating historical trends to 2050, incineration rates are predicted to increase to 50%, recycling to 44%, and discarded waste is estimated to decline to a mere 6%.” This tells us that between 2015 and 2050, the incineration of plastic waste is predicted to increase from representing 25% of global plastic disposal to representing 50% of global plastic disposal. This two-fold increase can be written as a 100% increase. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. 37.5% – is incorrect because incineration rates are expected to go from 25% in 2015 to 50% in 2050, which is a two-fold increase. Option B. 50% – is incorrect because incineration rates are expected to go from 25% in 2015 to 50% in 2050, which is a two-fold increase. Option C. 75% – is incorrect because incineration rates are expected to go from 25% in 2015 to 50% in 2050, which is a two-fold increase.

question.text: A marine biologist is interested in characterizing the concentration of microplastics within a population of deep-sea fish. Several of his research students are tasked with the responsibility of determining the parts of the fish that have the greatest levels of microplastics. Based on the research discussed in this passage, where would you hypothesize the students found the greatest levels of microplastic?

options.label: A.
options.text: In the caudal fin and the liver

options.label: D.
options.text: In the atria of the heart

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should locate the section of the text discussing the impacts of plastic on wildlife and then apply the information gleaned from this part of the passage to the stem. Paragraphs 6 to 9 discuss impacts on wildlife, with paragraph 9 mentioning the impacts of microplastics on fish: “…microplastics appear to concentrate within the gut and the digestive tracts of fish, parts not typically consumed by humans.” This tells us that the students probably found the greatest concentrations of microplastic within the esophagus and intestines of the fish, both parts of the digestive tract. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. In the caudal fin and the liver – is incorrect because, although the liver is an organ associated with the digestive system, the caudal fin is not; therefore, this would only be partially correct. Option C. In the operculum and gills – is incorrect because operculum and gills are not part of the GI tract, where paragraph 9 specifies the highest concentrations of microplastics would be found. Option D. In the atria of the heart – is incorrect because the Atria of the heart is part of the circulatory system, not the digestive system, where paragraph 9 specifies the highest concentrations of microplastics would be found.
