As Tom Downdall, the owner of Transformative Change Consulting, very aptly stated in response to the popular focus on recyclability and recycling: “Solving the plastic pollution crisis requires focus on another ‘R’—Responsibility.” If everyone, from multi-million-dollar companies to singular individuals, were to assume the responsibility and become intentional in their efforts to combat the plastic pollution crisis, then perhaps there might still be hope.

question.text: By how many folds did plastic production increase between 1950 – 2015?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should search the passage for a paragraph that shares statistics relating to plastic production over the decades. Paragraph 3 contains these figures and reads: “Global plastic production started to take off rapidly in the 1950s. While production was estimated to have been only 2 million tonnes annually in 1950, by 2015, plastic production was recorded to be 381 million tonnes per year, an increase of approximately 200-fold . By now, the world has already produced 78 billion tonnes of plastic.” This tells us that plastic production rose approximately 200-fold between 1950 and 2015. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. 10 – is incorrect because, in paragraph 3, the author says, “Fast forward to 2015, 381 million tonnes per year of plastic production was recorded, an increase of approximately 200-fold,” not 10-fold. Option B. 50 – is incorrect because, in paragraph 3, the author says, “while production was estimated to have been only 2 million tonnes annually in 1950, by 2015, plastic production was recorded to be 381 million tonnes per year, an increase of approximately 200-fold,” not 50-fold. Option C. 100 – is incorrect because, in paragraph 3, the author says, “while production was estimated to have been only 2 million tonnes annually in 1950, by 2015, plastic production was recorded to be 381 million tonnes per year, an increase of approximately 200-fold,” not 100-fold. Option E. 2000 – is incorrect because in paragraph 3, the author says, “while production was estimated to have been only 2 million tonnes annually in 1950, by 2015, plastic production was recorded to be 381 million tonnes per year, an increase of approximately 200-fold,” not 2000-fold.

passage.title: Passage 2
passage.text:
(1). The plastic pollution crisis has escalated to the point where it has now become a global issue. It is estimated that by 2030, the amount of plastic pollution on the planet will double; if this epidemic continues, by 2050, there will be far more plastic than fish in the sea. But how did this crisis begin?

(2). Plastic is synthesized by assembling long-chain molecules from single repetitive units known as monomers; with the addition of heat, pressure, and catalysts, chemical reactions are performed to link such monomers together. Typically, the monomers used in plastic synthesis are derived from fossil fuels (crude oil and natural gas). Polyethylene terephthalate (or PET) is a commonly used polymer that is found in the manufacturing of bottles and clothing, while Bakelite, or polyoxybenzylmethylenglycolanhydride, was the first synthetic plastic produced in 1907.

(3). Global plastic production started to take off rapidly in the 1950s. While production was estimated to have been only 2 million tonnes annually in 1950, by 2015, plastic production was recorded to be 381 million tonnes per year, an increase of approximately 200-fold. By now, the world has already produced 78 billion tonnes of plastic.

(4). After the end of the Second World War, materials developed for use during combat such as polyethylene (a product originally used to insulate radar cables), were adapted for post-war applications, and became widely used as consumer plastics. Prior to the mid-20th century, consumer goods were made from traditional materials like wood, glass, and metal. However, techniques such as injection molding allowed plastic to be produced more efficiently than these materials and in greater quantities, lowering their overall cost and making them more accessible to the growing middle class of the post-war era. The economic boom that followed the war further led to the growth of consumer culture and plastics rapidly became the material of choice for a wide range of goods, from kitchen utensils to children’s toys. Thus, plastics transformed everyday life, becoming integral to society as we know it today.

(5). The appetite for plastic seems to stem from its irresistibly attractive qualities, such as its lightweight nature, flexibility, versatility, strength, water-resistant capacity, and most of all, its relatively cheap cost; however, people’s insatiable desire for the material has resulted in the over-consumption of plastic goods. Although its durability and slow-to-degrade nature allowed plastics to be utilized in mass production, the large-scale use of plastic has come at a high cost. Over time, plastic has lingered as waste, waste that has slowly suffocated wildlife, adversely impacted human health, and polluted the environment.

(6). Improperly discarded plastic can impact our wildlife via three crucial routes, the first being “entanglement,” which is the entrapping, encircling, or constricting of marine animals by plastic debris. In most cases, wildlife becomes entangled in plastic ropes and netting and/or discarded fishing gear, while entanglement due to plastic packaging has also been documented.

(7). The second route is via the “ingestion” of plastic, which can occur intentionally due to an animal mistaking plastic for food, or unintentionally and indirectly, for instance, via the ingestion of prey species that contain plastic. Additionally, tiny pieces of plastic such as plastic fibers may accidentally be taken up by filter-feeding oysters or mussels. As we travel upwards on the food chain, ingesting such toxic material becomes increasingly deadly due to bioaccumulation and thus, would pose a huge risk to iconic creatures such as sharks and other predators at the top of our ocean’s food chains. In larger fish, scientists have recorded the presence of cigarette packets, food packaging, and plastic films; in some extreme cases, a rope, hose, flowerpots, and plastic sheeting have been found in sperm whales. Consumption of large volumes of plastic can have varied biological effects, such as decreased stomach capacity, poor appetite, and a misleading sense of satiation. The specific impact of reduced food intake in certain organisms has been carefully investigated and documented by researchers. For instance, it results in a slower metabolic rate and survival in Asian green mussels, reduced reproducibility in copepods, reduced growth and development of langoustine, and decreased energy stores in shore crabs. Other effects include obstruction or perforation of the gut, gastric rupture, ulcerative lesions, and even death. Some of the biochemical responses to plastic ingestion are metabolic disruption, decreased enzyme activity, cellular necrosis, and oxidative stress.

(8). The third crucial route by which plastic debris affects wildlife is through “interaction.” This includes contact with plastic waste through collisions, obstructions, and abrasions. One simple example is fishing gear, which can cause damage to coral reef ecosystems and other marine wildlife upon collision. Plastic debris can also interfere with substrate availability and disrupt light penetration and oxygen exchange.

(9). Research on the exposure and impact of microplastics (plastic particles >4.75 mm in diameter) on human health is ongoing. The smaller the particle size (micro-and nano-range), the greater the concern for human health. Possible routes of exposure to these minuscule particles include consumption through water and marine products, exposure to the skin via cosmetics, or inhalation of particles in the air. Research suggests that, for humans, the danger due to uptake of microplastics through diet is limited; microplastics appear to concentrate within the gut and the digestive tracts of fish, parts not typically consumed by humans. However, plastic fibers have also been detected in honey, beer, and table salt. To date, research only indicates negligible health risks from such exposure, though the mechanisms of microplastic interaction within the body are yet to be discovered, if at all. A study of North Sea fish suggested that plastic does not persist for a long duration within the organism; thus, one hypothesis is that plastic particles may directly exit through the GI tract without any negative impact, which would indeed bring about a wave of relief. However, such results may be met with skepticism and can perhaps only begin to be accepted once such studies are replicated, and findings are deemed reliable. It is hoped that future studies will better characterize the potential risks of microplastics and their impact on human health.

(10). Although the long-term effects of microplastics on human health have not been proven, the consumption of these particles could potentially lead to a host of troubling issues. For instance, microplastics may irritate the lining of the digestive tract and, if able to enter vital organs such as the brain or liver, could disrupt the body’s normal functions. In the long term, the ingestion of microplastics may cause developmental, reproductive, and metabolic disorders. If microplastics were to carry with them dangerous microorganisms from the environment, this could also cause infections within the body. Microplastics may impact the human immune system, resulting in chronic inflammation or immune-related diseases. Additionally, it has been suggested that microplastics can cause cancer because certain additives in plastic are known to be carcinogenic, including a compound known as “styrene.” Repeated exposure to carcinogenic materials, such as through the repeated consumption of microplastics containing these particles, could feasibly increase one’s risk of the disease.

(11). Plastic waste is commonly handled in one of three ways: through recycling, incineration (the burning of any given material), or disposal in landfills. A meta-study analyzed the impact of each method across factors, such as its global warming potential (GWP) and its total energy use (TEU). Across nearly all studies examined, recycling appears to be the most suitable option. Still, a few caveats must be noted. For instance, plastics can usually only be recycled once or twice; following this, they either end up in a landfill or must be incinerated. As such, recycling seems only to delay, rather than prevent, incineration and disposal. Also, recycling may not be the most economically favorable choice because recycled material is not necessarily a one-for-one displacement of primary plastic production. In other words, each tonne of recycled material does not prevent one tonne of primary material from being produced. This is due to the nature of the recycling process, which often results in products of lower economic value termed as “downcycling.”

(12). In the 1980s and prior, plastic was largely discarded, while recycling and incineration were negligible. Incineration and recycling rates began to increase from 1980 and 1990, respectively, by approximately 0.7% per year; by 2015, about half of the global plastic waste was discarded, a quarter incinerated, and another quarter recycled. Extrapolating historical trends to 2050, incineration rates are predicted to increase to 50%, recycling to 44%, and discarded waste is estimated to decline to a mere 6%.

(13). Although the potential increase in the recycling trend is to our advantage, the same cannot be said for the predicted incline in incineration rates. The burning of plastic can release toxic chemicals, such as hydrochloric acid, sulfur dioxide, heavy metals, and other carcinogens that can have adverse effects on the human body, but the horror does not stop there. Incineration of plastic has several environmental impacts as well – these include the production of greenhouse gases, such as carbon dioxide (CO2), which contributes to climate change, the incomplete combustion of Polyethylene (PE), Polypropylene (PP), and Polystyrene (PS), which can release toxic gases such as carbon monoxide (CO). Additionally, polyvinyl chloride (PVC) can produce dioxins, which are persistent organic pollutants (POPs). Therefore, to avoid such detrimental effects, it is necessary to prevent the open or uncontrolled incineration of plastics.

(14). High-income countries have invested in the regulation of waste management and incinerator sites by monitoring the emissions and potential leakages to the environment. Modern incinerators have been designed to combat the issue of dioxins and other toxic emissions by ensuring efficient combustion, selective catalytic reduction, end-of-pipe treatment, and the addition of appropriate inhibitors. A testament to the success of such technologies has been evidenced by a study conducted in Belgium where no increase was recorded in the dioxin-serum levels of those working in municipal incinerator facilities compared to the high exposure rates they would have experienced if such methods were not in place. However, in low-to-middle income countries where such incinerator technologies are vastly absent and environmental regulations are laxer, the open burning of municipal waste is a continual occurrence. The adoption of modern, efficient, low-risk technologies is required on the global scale to convert incineration into a universally safe solution for plastic waste management.

(15). Once plastic enters our oceans via coastlines, tides, rivers, and marine waters, its accumulation and dispersion patterns are determined by oceanic surface currents and winds. The buoyant nature of plastic allows it to float on oceanic surfaces, and because of being carried by the wind, plastics tend to agglomerate in oceanic gyres, with the greatest concentration at the center of ocean basins. Basins located in the Northern Hemisphere were recorded to have the greatest concentration of plastics, a predictable outcome because most of the world’s population resides within the Northern Hemisphere. Although the quantity of plastic clustered in Southern oceans was relatively lesser than in the Northern oceans, the amount was of the same order of magnitude as the Northern; this was surprising as there is a lack of coastal populations and plastic inputs in the Southern Hemisphere. This unexpected finding suggests that plastic pollution can be transported between oceanic gyres and basins to a significantly greater degree than once hypothesized.

(16). So, what is the solution? A plethora of ideas has been suggested, with many underways. But, the question remains, will all, or any, of them, be successful? As Tom Downdall, the owner of Transformative Change Consulting, very aptly stated in response to the popular focus on recyclability and recycling: “Solving the plastic pollution crisis requires focus on another ‘R’—Responsibility.” If everyone, from multi-million-dollar companies to singular individuals, were to assume the responsibility and become intentional in their efforts to combat the plastic pollution crisis, then perhaps there might still be hope.

question.text: Each of the following are produced (directly or indirectly) by the incineration of plastic EXCEPT one. Which one of the following is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should search the passage for the paragraph or paragraphs discussing plastic waste incineration. If we note that this is mentioned in paragraphs 11–14, we should then scan these paragraphs for references to the toxic emissions created by plastic waste incineration. This is addressed in paragraph 13: “Incineration of plastic has several environmental impacts as well – these include the production of greenhouse gases, such as carbon dioxide (CO 2) , which contributes to climate change, the incomplete combustion of Polyethylene (PE), Polypropylene (PP), and Polystyrene (PS), which can release toxic gases such as carbon monoxide (CO). Additionally, polyvinyl chloride (PVC) can produce dioxins, which are persistent organic pollutants (POPs).” This tells us that the incineration of plastic produces carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, and POPs. Carbon disulfide is the only answer choice NOT mentioned. Therefore, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Carbon dioxide – is incorrect because, in paragraph 13, the author mentions, “Incineration of plastic has several environmental impacts as well – these include the production of greenhouse gases, such as carbon dioxide (CO 2) , which contributes to climate change, the incomplete combustion of Polyethylene (PE), Polypropylene (PP), and Polystyrene (PS), which can release toxic gases such as carbon monoxide (CO). Additionally, polyvinyl chloride (PVC) can produce dioxins, which are persistent organic pollutants (POPs).” Since carbon dioxide is mentioned, it cannot be the answer. Option B. Carbon monoxide – is incorrect because, in paragraph 13, the author mentions, “Incineration of plastic has several environmental impacts as well…the incomplete combustion of…can release toxic gases such as carbon monoxide (CO).” Since carbon monoxide is mentioned, it cannot be the answer. Option D. POPs – is incorrect because, in paragraph 13, the author mentions, “Incineration of plastic has several environmental impacts as well…Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) can produce dioxins, which are persistent organic pollutants (POPs).” Since POPs are mentioned, it cannot be the answer.

passage.title: Passage 3
passage.text:
(1). Alfred Binet was unlike other Psychologists at the beginning of the 20 th century. The primary focus of psychology at this time was understanding people who were different from the norm. This included why people felt, acted, or thought in unusual ways. Interestingly, Binet was interested in the very opposite of this notion. He wanted to define what was normal, specifically relating to mental capacity and intelligence. What defines an individual as highly intelligent, and where is the average?

(2). Binet began to understand that many people were considered smart because they understood the laws of physics or could recite Shakespearean literature. He considered these skills as outcomes of higher education, which made him wonder if there was a way to measure intelligence regardless of education.

(3). Binet proceeded to design a test to quantify the innate ability of a normal person. This would help French officials identify students who were in danger of falling behind in school. This innate ability was, and still is, referred to as an intelligence quotient, or IQ for short. Binet’s original test for children had them put things in order and identify patterns, to which education offered no advantage.

(4). IQ is reported as a number on a scale, with 100 being the average for an individual’s age. Consider a 7-year-old boy who scores an IQ of 100 on Binet’s test. This boy is theoretically able to perform Binet’s tasks just as well as most other 7-year-olds. However, if he were to score a 110, he would be above average for his age. Mathematically, a large random sample of 7-year-old kids would have an average IQ score of 100. This marks the 50 th percentile, as a score of 100 will be higher than 50% of the group. 34% of the kids would have an IQ score between 85 and 100, and another 34% of the kids would score between 100 and 115. This means that 68% of the kids will score within 85 and 115. All the percentage ranges below an IQ score of 115 add up to 84%. This means that this score marks the 84 th percentile, as 84% of individuals will score below 115. This symmetrical standard distribution of test scores is commonly known as the bell curve (Figure 1).

Figure 1: Standard bell curve of IQ test scores

(5). Theoretically, an individual’s IQ will stay the same throughout one’s life, as there are different tests for different ages. A 7-year-old will be scored against the average 7-year-old. When that same child is 10 years old, he will be scored against other 10-year-old children with more challenging questions, or more difficult grading schemes. The type of IQ test also plays an important role, as there are multiple tests currently available.

(6). Lewis Terman of Stanford University developed the Stanford-Binet Intelligence Test, which is an American adaptation of Binet’s original French test. Psychologist David Wechsler did not like either of these tests as they required a good grasp of language to do well. What if someone had a reading disability or poor linguistic education? The resulting IQ test is known as the Weschler Intelligence Scale, and consists of two parts. The first part is much like the Stanford-Binet test; it is called a verbal IQ score and is often close to a person’s Stanford-Binet IQ. The second part includes tasks that don’t require people to be good with words. For instance, identifying patterns in pictures is one of several wordless tasks. This part yields a performance IQ score, which may be extremely different from one’s verbal IQ score. Discrepancies in these two scores may help psychologists and teachers identify the presence of a language deficiency or reading disability. A third and final IQ score produced by the Wechsler scale is overall IQ, which averages the performance IQ and verbal IQ. Consistently, all IQ tests will exhibit a standard bell curve of scores within a random sample, with 100 always representing the average score.

(7). Standardized reading comprehension assessments also score participants in a standard bell curve with an average of 100, but they do not indicate IQ. They merely indicate a global view of a child’s reading ability, which may provide useful instructions and interventions to improve reading capabilities. The Simple View of Reading (SVR) is a framework that identifies word recognition and oral language comprehension as the two primary components involved in reading comprehension. An SVR standardized reading comprehension assessment will thereby grade students on these two components.

(8). Word recognition encompasses phonological awareness, automaticity of word recognition, and other phonic skills. There are three subtests that grade these skills: (1) word attack, which has students sound out gibberish words; (2) word identification, which analyzes a student’s verbal pronunciation while reading a passage; (3) spelling, which has students spell simple and complex words. The scores of these three tests will indicate how a student’s word recognition abilities compare to other students of the same age.

(9). Oral Language comprehension encompasses oral vocabulary, morphology, sentence comprehension, and pragmatic language. There are three subtests that grade these skills: (1) listening comprehension, which tests a student’s ability to recall a verbal story; (2) reading comprehension, which tests a student’s ability to recall a written passage; (3) vocabulary, which tests the quantity of words that a student knows. The scores of these three tests indicate how a student’s oral language comprehension abilities compare to other students of the same age.

(10). Consider Abby, a fourth-grade student who recently completed an SVR standardized reading comprehension assessment (Table 1). Abby can effectively recall details of stories read aloud, recall details from written passages, and is able to consistently use accurate vocabulary in speech. On the other hand, her reading is not fluent, her reading pace is slow, she frequently sounds out written words, and her spelling is below average. Her test results indicate weak word recognition skills and strong oral language comprehension skills (Table 1).

Table 1: Abby’s test results

Primary Skill

Subtest

Score

Oral Language Comprehension

Listening Comprehension

115

Reading Comprehension

100

Vocabulary

115

Word Recognition

Word Attack

70

Word Identification

85

Spelling

72

(11). Abby’s test scores, which indicate strong oral language comprehension skills and poor word recognition skills, is referred to as a first profile reading difficulty. Students under this profile may perform well in class discussions, but will have trouble on spelling and reading tests. In severe cases, this profile can indicate the presence of SLD/Dyslexia. A second profile reading disorder is classified by the opposite; strong word recognition skills and weak oral language comprehension. Students under this profile may perform well on spelling and reading tests, but will have difficulties expressing their ideas and comprehending verbal lectures. Finally, a third profile reading difficulty is indicated by a mix of strengths and weaknesses in both word recognition and oral language comprehension, with no clear discrepancy between the two.

(12). Importantly, taking a standardized test is completely optional. Parents do not necessarily need their children to take any of these tests. However, the information received from the results of a child’s performance can provide information regarding their intellectual development and potential, which may identify the need for additional educational resources that target areas of weakness.

question.text: Which of the following conclusions can be drawn about Abby’s reading abilities based on her word attack score?

options.label: A.
options.text: Abby may have poor word recognition skills

options.label: B.
options.text: Abby may have limited oral language comprehension

options.label: C.
options.text: Abby may have excellent word recognition abilities

options.label: D.
options.text: Abby may have excellent oral language comprehension

options.label: E.
options.text: Abby may excel in both oral language comprehension and word recognition

correct_answer_text: Abby may have poor word recognition skills

explanation.concept_text: Paragraph 10 states that Abby’s: “…tests results indicate weak word recognition skills and strong oral language comprehension skills.” Additionally, paragraph 11 also states that: “Abby’s test scores, which indicate strong oral language comprehension skills and poor word recognition skills, is referred to as a first profile reading difficulty.” Evidently, Abby’s overall test results indicate that she may have weak word recognition abilities. You can also obtain this answer by assessing Abby’s score and using passage information to arrive at the same conclusion. For example, paragraph 8 states: “There are three subtests that grade these [word recognition] skills: (1) word attack, which has students sound out gibberish words; (2) word identification, which analyzes a student’s verbal pronunciation while reading a passage; (3) spelling, which has students spell simple and complex words.” This illustrates that word attack is a skill that indicates word recognition abilities, amongst others. Next, refer to Table 1, which states that Abby scored a 70 on the word attack section. Table 1 also shows that word attack is a subcategory of word recognition. To interpret Abby’s score, refer to the passage’s discussion on evaluating IQ scores, which can be found in paragraph 4. Specifically, Figure 1, which displays a standard bell curve distribution, can be used to identify what percentile Abby’s score falls under. This curve indicates that a score of 70 marks the 2nd percentile. This score is evidently way below the average 50th percentile, which corresponds to a score of 100. Thus, Abby has significantly weak word recognition abilities. Therefore, Option A is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Abby may have limited oral language comprehension – is incorrect because paragraph 8 states that: “There are three subtests that grade these [word recognition] skills: (1) word attack, which has students sound out gibberish words…” Thus, word attack score indicates word recognition skills, NOT oral comprehension abilities. Additionally, this option contradicts the passage because paragraph 10 states that Abby’s “…tests results indicate weak word recognition skills and strong oral language comprehension skills.” Option C. Abby may have excellent word recognition abilities – is incorrect because this option contradicts the passage because paragraph 10 states that Abby’s “…test results indicate weak word recognition skills and strong oral language comprehension skills.” Additionally, Table 1 shows that Abby scored 70 on the word attack section. According to Figure 1, this means that Abby scored in the 2 nd percentile. This is way below the average 50 th percentile, which corresponds to a score of 100. Thus, Abby has significantly weak, NOT excellent, word recognition abilities. Option D. Abby may have excellent oral language comprehension – is incorrect because paragraph 8 states that: “There are three subtests that grade these [word recognition] skills: (1) word attack, which has students sound out gibberish words…” Thus, the word attack score indicates word recognition skills, NOT oral comprehension abilities. Option E. Abby may excel in both oral language comprehension and word recognition – is incorrect because paragraph 8 states that: “There are three subtests that grade these [word recognition] skills: (1) word attack, which has students sound out gibberish words…” Thus, word attack score indicates word recognition skills, NOT oral comprehension abilities. Additionally, Abby does not have strong word recognition abilities as demonstrated by paragraph 10 which states that Abby’s “…test results indicate weak word recognition skills and strong oral language comprehension skills.”

question.text: Which of the following conclusions can be drawn about Abby's reading abilities using her vocabulary score?

options.label: A.
options.text: Abby may have poor word recognition skills

options.label: B.
options.text: Abby may have limited oral language comprehension

options.label: C.
options.text: Abby may have excellent word recognition abilities

options.label: D.
options.text: Abby may have excellent oral language comprehension

options.label: E.
options.text: Abby may have poor oral language comprehension and word recognition

correct_answer_text: Abby may have excellent oral language comprehension

explanation.concept_text: Paragraph 10 states that Abby’s: “…test results indicate weak word recognition skills and strong oral language comprehension skills.” Additionally, paragraph 11 also states that: “Abby’s test scores, which indicate strong oral language comprehension skills and poor word recognition skills, is referred to as a first profile reading difficulty.” Evidently, Abby’s overall test results indicate that she may have strong oral language comprehension abilities. You can also obtain this answer by assessing Abby’s score and using passage information to arrive at the same conclusion. For example, paragraph 9 states: “There are three subtests that grade these [oral language comprehension] skills: (1) listening comprehension, which tests a student’s ability to recall a verbal story; (2) reading comprehension, which tests a student’s ability to recall a written passage; (3) vocabulary, which tests the quantity of words that a student knows.” This illustrates that vocabulary is a skill that indicates oral language comprehension skills, amongst others. Next, refer to Table 1, which states that Abby scored a 115 on the vocabulary section. Table 1 also shows that vocabulary is a subcategory of oral language comprehension. To interpret Abby’s score, refer to the passage’s discussion on evaluating IQ scores, which can be found in paragraph 4. Specifically, Figure 1, which displays a standard bell curve distribution, can be used to identify what percentile Abby’s score falls under. This curve indicates that a score of 115 marks the 84th percentile. This score is evidently way above the average 50th percentile, which corresponds to a score of 100. Thus, Abby has significantly strong oral language comprehension abilities. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Abby may have poor word recognition skills – is incorrect because paragraph 9 states: “There are three subtests that grade these [oral language comprehension] skills: […] (3) vocabulary, which tests the quantity of words that a student knows.” Thus, the vocabulary score indicates oral language comprehension skills, NOT word recognition abilities. Option B. Abby may have limited oral language comprehension – is incorrect because this option contradicts the passage because paragraph 10 states that Abby’s “…test results indicate weak word recognition skills and strong oral language comprehension skills.” Additionally, Table 1 states that Abby scored 115 on the vocabulary section. According to Figure 1, this means that Abby scored in the 84 th percentile. This is way above the average 50 th percentile, which corresponds to a score of 100. Thus, Abby has significantly strong, NOT weak, oral language comprehension abilities. Option C. Abby may have excellent word recognition abilities – is incorrect because paragraph 9 states: “There are three subtests that grade these [oral language comprehension] skills: […] (3) vocabulary, which tests the quantity of words that a student knows.” Thus, the vocabulary score indicates oral language comprehension skills, NOT word recognition abilities. Option E. Abby may have poor oral language comprehension and word recognition – is incorrect because paragraph 9 states that “There are three subtests that grade these [oral language comprehension] skills: […] (3) vocabulary, which tests the quantity of words that a student knows.” Thus, the vocabulary score indicates oral language comprehension skills, NOT word recognition abilities. Additionally, Abby does not have weak oral language comprehension abilities as demonstrated by paragraph 10 which states that Abby’s “…test results indicate weak word recognition skills and strong oral language comprehension skills.”

passage.title: Passage 3
passage.text:
(1). Alfred Binet was unlike other Psychologists at the beginning of the 20 th century. The primary focus of psychology at this time was understanding people who were different from the norm. This included why people felt, acted, or thought in unusual ways. Interestingly, Binet was interested in the very opposite of this notion. He wanted to define what was normal, specifically relating to mental capacity and intelligence. What defines an individual as highly intelligent, and where is the average?

(2). Binet began to understand that many people were considered smart because they understood the laws of physics or could recite Shakespearean literature. He considered these skills as outcomes of higher education, which made him wonder if there was a way to measure intelligence regardless of education.

(3). Binet proceeded to design a test to quantify the innate ability of a normal person. This would help French officials identify students who were in danger of falling behind in school. This innate ability was, and still is, referred to as an intelligence quotient, or IQ for short. Binet’s original test for children had them put things in order and identify patterns, to which education offered no advantage.

(4). IQ is reported as a number on a scale, with 100 being the average for an individual’s age. Consider a 7-year-old boy who scores an IQ of 100 on Binet’s test. This boy is theoretically able to perform Binet’s tasks just as well as most other 7-year-olds. However, if he were to score a 110, he would be above average for his age. Mathematically, a large random sample of 7-year-old kids would have an average IQ score of 100. This marks the 50 th percentile, as a score of 100 will be higher than 50% of the group. 34% of the kids would have an IQ score between 85 and 100, and another 34% of the kids would score between 100 and 115. This means that 68% of the kids will score within 85 and 115. All the percentage ranges below an IQ score of 115 add up to 84%. This means that this score marks the 84 th percentile, as 84% of individuals will score below 115. This symmetrical standard distribution of test scores is commonly known as the bell curve (Figure 1).

Figure 1: Standard bell curve of IQ test scores

(5). Theoretically, an individual’s IQ will stay the same throughout one’s life, as there are different tests for different ages. A 7-year-old will be scored against the average 7-year-old. When that same child is 10 years old, he will be scored against other 10-year-old children with more challenging questions, or more difficult grading schemes. The type of IQ test also plays an important role, as there are multiple tests currently available.

(6). Lewis Terman of Stanford University developed the Stanford-Binet Intelligence Test, which is an American adaptation of Binet’s original French test. Psychologist David Wechsler did not like either of these tests as they required a good grasp of language to do well. What if someone had a reading disability or poor linguistic education? The resulting IQ test is known as the Weschler Intelligence Scale, and consists of two parts. The first part is much like the Stanford-Binet test; it is called a verbal IQ score and is often close to a person’s Stanford-Binet IQ. The second part includes tasks that don’t require people to be good with words. For instance, identifying patterns in pictures is one of several wordless tasks. This part yields a performance IQ score, which may be extremely different from one’s verbal IQ score. Discrepancies in these two scores may help psychologists and teachers identify the presence of a language deficiency or reading disability. A third and final IQ score produced by the Wechsler scale is overall IQ, which averages the performance IQ and verbal IQ. Consistently, all IQ tests will exhibit a standard bell curve of scores within a random sample, with 100 always representing the average score.

(7). Standardized reading comprehension assessments also score participants in a standard bell curve with an average of 100, but they do not indicate IQ. They merely indicate a global view of a child’s reading ability, which may provide useful instructions and interventions to improve reading capabilities. The Simple View of Reading (SVR) is a framework that identifies word recognition and oral language comprehension as the two primary components involved in reading comprehension. An SVR standardized reading comprehension assessment will thereby grade students on these two components.

(8). Word recognition encompasses phonological awareness, automaticity of word recognition, and other phonic skills. There are three subtests that grade these skills: (1) word attack, which has students sound out gibberish words; (2) word identification, which analyzes a student’s verbal pronunciation while reading a passage; (3) spelling, which has students spell simple and complex words. The scores of these three tests will indicate how a student’s word recognition abilities compare to other students of the same age.

(9). Oral Language comprehension encompasses oral vocabulary, morphology, sentence comprehension, and pragmatic language. There are three subtests that grade these skills: (1) listening comprehension, which tests a student’s ability to recall a verbal story; (2) reading comprehension, which tests a student’s ability to recall a written passage; (3) vocabulary, which tests the quantity of words that a student knows. The scores of these three tests indicate how a student’s oral language comprehension abilities compare to other students of the same age.

(10). Consider Abby, a fourth-grade student who recently completed an SVR standardized reading comprehension assessment (Table 1). Abby can effectively recall details of stories read aloud, recall details from written passages, and is able to consistently use accurate vocabulary in speech. On the other hand, her reading is not fluent, her reading pace is slow, she frequently sounds out written words, and her spelling is below average. Her test results indicate weak word recognition skills and strong oral language comprehension skills (Table 1).

Table 1: Abby’s test results

Primary Skill

Subtest

Score

Oral Language Comprehension

Listening Comprehension

115

Reading Comprehension

100

Vocabulary

115

Word Recognition

Word Attack

70

Word Identification

85

Spelling

72

(11). Abby’s test scores, which indicate strong oral language comprehension skills and poor word recognition skills, is referred to as a first profile reading difficulty. Students under this profile may perform well in class discussions, but will have trouble on spelling and reading tests. In severe cases, this profile can indicate the presence of SLD/Dyslexia. A second profile reading disorder is classified by the opposite; strong word recognition skills and weak oral language comprehension. Students under this profile may perform well on spelling and reading tests, but will have difficulties expressing their ideas and comprehending verbal lectures. Finally, a third profile reading difficulty is indicated by a mix of strengths and weaknesses in both word recognition and oral language comprehension, with no clear discrepancy between the two.

(12). Importantly, taking a standardized test is completely optional. Parents do not necessarily need their children to take any of these tests. However, the information received from the results of a child’s performance can provide information regarding their intellectual development and potential, which may identify the need for additional educational resources that target areas of weakness.

question.text: Which of the following most accurately reflects Abby’s reading comprehension skills?

options.label: E.
options.text: There is insufficient information to judge Abby’s reading comprehension skills

explanation.concept_text: Table 1 indicates that Abby scored 100 on reading comprehension. To analyze this score, refer to paragraph 4 which discusses the bell curve distribution of test scores. Here, the author writes that a score of 100: “…marks the 50th percentile , as a score of 100 will be higher than 50% of the group.” Thus, Abby scored in the 50th percentile. This is also reinforced by looking at Figure 1 which shows that a score of 100 corresponds to the 50th percentile. The author explains that being in this percentile means that Abby’s score is higher than 50th percent of the group. 50% of the people that take this test will score below Abby while 50% will score higher. Abby is thus, in the middle. In other words, Abby scored an average score. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Below average – is incorrect because Table 1 shows that Abby scored 100 on the reading comprehension which “…marks the 50 th percentile, as a score of 100 will be higher than 50% of the group.” (Paragraph 4). Figure 1 also shows that Abby scored in the middle of the bell curve. This indicates that 50% of people will score higher and 50% will score lower than Abby. Thus, Abby’s score is not below average, rather it is at the average mark. Option C. Above average – is incorrect because Table 1 shows that Abby scored 100 on the reading comprehension which “…marks the 50 th percentile, as a score of 100 will be higher than 50% of the group.” (Paragraph 4). Figure 1 also shows that Abby scored in the middle of the bell curve. This indicates that 50% of people will score higher and 50% will score lower than Abby. Thus, Abby’s score is not above average, rather it is at the average mark. Option D. Genius level – is incorrect because Table 1 shows that Abby scored 100 on the reading comprehension which “…marks the 50 th percentile, as a score of 100 will be higher than 50% of the group.” (Paragraph 4). Figure 1 also shows that Abby scored in the middle of the bell curve. This indicates that 50% of people will score higher and 50% will score lower than Abby. Thus, Abby’s score is not genius level, rather it is at the average mark. A genius score is represented by a very high score, such as 145+, that a few percent of students achieve. Option E. There is insufficient information to judge Abby’s reading comprehension skills – is incorrect because there IS enough information to draw a conclusion regarding Abby’s reading comprehension skills. Table 1 shows that Abby scored 100 on the reading comprehension which “…marks the 50 th percentile, as a score of 100 will be higher than 50% of the group.” (Paragraph 4). Figure 1 also shows that Abby scored in the middle of the bell curve. This indicates that 50% of people will score higher and 50% will score lower than Abby, demonstrating that Abby’s reading comprehension skills are average.

question.text: Each of the following represent scores provided by the Weschler Intelligence Scale EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: Paragraph 6 states: “The resulting IQ test is known as the Weschler Intelligence Scale , and consists of two parts. The first part is much like the Stanford-Binet test; it is called a verbal IQ score […] The second part includes tasks that don’t require people to be good with words. For instance, identifying patterns in pictures is one of several wordless tasks. This part yields a performance IQ score, […] A third and final IQ score produced by the Wechsler scale is overall IQ , which averages the performance IQ and verbal IQ.” Verbal, performance, and overall IQ scores are all mentioned in regards to the Weschler Intelligence scale, however, relative IQ score is not. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Verbal IQ score – is incorrect because paragraph 6 states: “The resulting IQ test is known as the Weschler Intelligence Scale, and consists of two parts. […] A third and final IQ score produced by the Wechsler scale is overall IQ, which averages the performance IQ and verbal IQ.” Since the overall IQ score is mentioned in regards to the Weschler Intelligence Scale, it is not an exception and so, cannot be the correct answer. question.text: Under which of the following percentiles would a student with an IQ score of 130 fall?

explanation.concept_text: Figure 1 shows that 2.1% of test takers score above 130, indicating that this score falls in the 98th percentile. Another way to arrive at this solution is to recognize that all the percentages below the 130 mark add up to the percentile for 130. This is evidenced by the example given in paragraph 4 when the author discusses an IQ score of 115. The passage states: “All the percentage ranges below an IQ score of 115 add up to 84%. This means that this score marks the 84 th percentile, as 84% of individuals will score below 115.” Thus, to arrive at the percentile rank for 130, add up the percentages below this score. These are: 96% + 2% + 0.1% = 98.1% Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. 2 nd percentile – is incorrect because Figure 1 shows that 2.1% of test takers score above 130, indicating that this score falls in the 98 th percentile. Additionally, the percentile rank can be determined by adding up the percentages below the score. For 130, these percentages are: 96% + 2% + 0.1% = 98.1%, indicating the 98 th percentile. The 2 nd percentile is indicated by an IQ score of 70. Option B. 34 th percentile – is incorrect because the percentile rank can be determined by adding up the percentages below the score. For 130, these percentages are: 96% + 2% + 0.1% = 98.1%, indicating the 98 th percentile. The 34% on Figure 1 does NOT correspond to a particular percentile. Rather, this number represents how “…34% of the kids would have an IQ score between 85 and 100, and another 34% of the kids would score between 100 and 115.” (Paragraph 4). Option C. 50 th percentile – is incorrect because the percentile rank can be determined by adding up the percentages below the score. For 130, these percentages are: 96% + 2% + 0.1% = 98.1%, indicating the 98 th percentile. Paragraph 4 clearly states that a score of 100 “…marks the 50 th percentile, as a score of 100 will be higher than 50% of the group.” Option E. 100 th percentile – is incorrect because the percentile rank can be determined by adding up the percentages below the score. For 130, these percentages are: 96% + 2% + 0.1% = 98.1%, indicating the 98 th percentile. A score above 145 corresponds to the 100 th percentile as only 0.1% of people achieve this score.

This marks the 50 th percentile, as a score of 100 will be higher than 50% of the group. 34% of the kids would have an IQ score between 85 and 100, and another 34% of the kids would score between 100 and 115. This means that 68% of the kids will score within 85 and 115. All the percentage ranges below an IQ score of 115 add up to 84%. This means that this score marks the 84 th percentile, as 84% of individuals will score below 115. This symmetrical standard distribution of test scores is commonly known as the bell curve (Figure 1).

Figure 1: Standard bell curve of IQ test scores

(5). Theoretically, an individual’s IQ will stay the same throughout one’s life, as there are different tests for different ages. A 7-year-old will be scored against the average 7-year-old. When that same child is 10 years old, he will be scored against other 10-year-old children with more challenging questions, or more difficult grading schemes. The type of IQ test also plays an important role, as there are multiple tests currently available.

(6). Lewis Terman of Stanford University developed the Stanford-Binet Intelligence Test, which is an American adaptation of Binet’s original French test. Psychologist David Wechsler did not like either of these tests as they required a good grasp of language to do well. What if someone had a reading disability or poor linguistic education? The resulting IQ test is known as the Weschler Intelligence Scale, and consists of two parts. The first part is much like the Stanford-Binet test; it is called a verbal IQ score and is often close to a person’s Stanford-Binet IQ. The second part includes tasks that don’t require people to be good with words. For instance, identifying patterns in pictures is one of several wordless tasks. This part yields a performance IQ score, which may be extremely different from one’s verbal IQ score. Discrepancies in these two scores may help psychologists and teachers identify the presence of a language deficiency or reading disability. A third and final IQ score produced by the Wechsler scale is overall IQ, which averages the performance IQ and verbal IQ. Consistently, all IQ tests will exhibit a standard bell curve of scores within a random sample, with 100 always representing the average score.

(7). Standardized reading comprehension assessments also score participants in a standard bell curve with an average of 100, but they do not indicate IQ. They merely indicate a global view of a child’s reading ability, which may provide useful instructions and interventions to improve reading capabilities. The Simple View of Reading (SVR) is a framework that identifies word recognition and oral language comprehension as the two primary components involved in reading comprehension. An SVR standardized reading comprehension assessment will thereby grade students on these two components.

(8). Word recognition encompasses phonological awareness, automaticity of word recognition, and other phonic skills. There are three subtests that grade these skills: (1) word attack, which has students sound out gibberish words; (2) word identification, which analyzes a student’s verbal pronunciation while reading a passage; (3) spelling, which has students spell simple and complex words. The scores of these three tests will indicate how a student’s word recognition abilities compare to other students of the same age.

(9). Oral Language comprehension encompasses oral vocabulary, morphology, sentence comprehension, and pragmatic language. There are three subtests that grade these skills: (1) listening comprehension, which tests a student’s ability to recall a verbal story; (2) reading comprehension, which tests a student’s ability to recall a written passage; (3) vocabulary, which tests the quantity of words that a student knows. The scores of these three tests indicate how a student’s oral language comprehension abilities compare to other students of the same age.

(10). Consider Abby, a fourth-grade student who recently completed an SVR standardized reading comprehension assessment (Table 1). Abby can effectively recall details of stories read aloud, recall details from written passages, and is able to consistently use accurate vocabulary in speech. On the other hand, her reading is not fluent, her reading pace is slow, she frequently sounds out written words, and her spelling is below average. Her test results indicate weak word recognition skills and strong oral language comprehension skills (Table 1).

Table 1: Abby’s test results

(11). Abby’s test scores, which indicate strong oral language comprehension skills and poor word recognition skills, is referred to as a first profile reading difficulty. Students under this profile may perform well in class discussions, but will have trouble on spelling and reading tests. In severe cases, this profile can indicate the presence of SLD/Dyslexia. A second profile reading disorder is classified by the opposite; strong word recognition skills and weak oral language comprehension. Students under this profile may perform well on spelling and reading tests, but will have difficulties expressing their ideas and comprehending verbal lectures. Finally, a third profile reading difficulty is indicated by a mix of strengths and weaknesses in both word recognition and oral language comprehension, with no clear discrepancy between the two.

(12). Importantly, taking a standardized test is completely optional. Parents do not necessarily need their children to take any of these tests. However, the information received from the results of a child’s performance can provide information regarding their intellectual development and potential, which may identify the need for additional educational resources that target areas of weakness.

question.text: Refer to Figure 1 for questions 39-42. Which of the following represents the percentage of 12-year-old IQ test takers that receive a result between 70 and 130?

explanation.concept_text: The passage explains how to determine the percentage of test-scorers within a range of scores in paragraph 4 when it states: “34% of the kids would have an IQ score between 85 and 100, and another 34% of the kids would score between 100 and 115. This means that 68% of the kids will score within 85 and 115.” Thus, to determine the percentage of people that score within a given range, you just add the percentages depicted in Figure 1 that fall within that range. For the 70-130 range, we do not even need to add up the percentages because the graph depicts this range to be 96% of test takers. Therefore, Option E is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. 4% – is incorrect because to determine the percentage of people that score within a given range, you just add the percentages depicted in Figure 1 that fall within that range. For the 70-130 range, we do not even need to add up the percentages because the graph depicts this range to be 96% of test takers. Notably, 4% is also too small a percentage to represent the number of people that score within such a large range. Option B. 14% – is incorrect because to determine the percentage of people that score within a given range, you just add the percentages depicted in Figure 1 that fall within that range. For the 70-130 range, we do not even need to add up the percentages because the graph depicts this range to be 96% of test takers. 14%, on the other hand, represents the percentage of people that score between 70-85 and 115-130. Option C. 34% – is incorrect because to determine the percentage of people that score within a given range, you just add the percentages depicted in Figure 1 that fall within that range. For the 70-130 range, we do not even need to add up the percentages because the graph depicts this range to be 96% of test takers. 34%, on the other hand, represents the percentage of people that score between 85-100 and 100-115. Option D. 68% – is incorrect because to determine the percentage of people that score within a given range, you just add the percentages depicted in Figure 1 that fall within that range. For the 70-130 range, we do not even need to add up the percentages because the graph depicts this range to be 96% of test takers. 68%, on the other hand, represents the percentage of people that score between 85-115.

question.text: Refer to Figure 1 for questions 39-42. Which of the following IQ scores indicate the 2 nd percentile?

explanation.concept_text: The passage explains how to determine the percentile using the standard bell curve distribution in paragraph 4 when it states: “Mathematically, a large random sample of 7-year-old kids would have an average IQ score of 100. This marks the 50th percentile, as a score of 100 will be higher than 50% of the group. […] All the percentage ranges below an IQ score of 115 add up to 84%. This means that this score marks the 84th percentile, as 84% of individuals will score below 115.” Thus, the percentile corresponds to the percentage of people that fall below a certain score. The 2nd percentile score would hence indicate that 2% of people score below that score. On Figure 1, this score is 70 . Therefore, Option A is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. 85 – is incorrect because the percentile corresponds to the percentage of people that fall below a certain score. The score of 85 on Figure 1 corresponds to the 16 th percentile as 16% of people fall below this score (14% + 2 % + 0.1%). The 2 nd percentile however, is indicated by a score of 70 as Figure 1 shows that 2% of people fall below this score. Option C. 100 – is incorrect because paragraph 4 states that an “…average IQ score of 100. This marks the 50 th percentile, as a score of 100 will be higher than 50% of the group.” Thus, a score of 100 represents the 50 th , NOT the 2 nd , percentile. Option D. 115 – is incorrect because paragraph 4 states that “All the percentage ranges below an IQ score of 115 add up to 84%. This means that this score marks the 84 th percentile, as 84% of individuals will score below 115.” Thus, a score of 115 represents the 84 th , NOT the 2 nd , percentile. Option E. 130 – is incorrect because the percentile corresponds to the percentage of people that fall below a certain score. The score of 130 on Figure 1 corresponds to the 98 th percentile as 98% of people fall below this score (96% + 2 % + 0.1%). The 2 nd percentile however, is indicated by a score of 70 as Figure 1 shows that 2% of people fall below this score.

question.text: A test taker with an unknown IQ would statistically fall within which of the following ranges?

explanation.concept_text: Paragraph 4 states that: “Mathematically, a large random sample of 7-year-old kids would have an average IQ score of 100. This marks the 50th percentile, as a score of 100 will be higher than 50% of the group. 34% of the kids would have an IQ score between 85 and 100 …” The average score is a 100. This score is in the 50th percentile which means that half of all test takers will obtain this score. A range of 85-100 represents 34% of people. As opposed to the other ranges present, this is the largest. Thus, statistically speaking, a random person’s IQ is most likely to fall within this range. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. 55-70 – is incorrect because Figure 1 illustrates that only 2% of people fall within the range of 55-70. Thus, it is unlikely that a random person’s IQ will fall within this range. Option C. 115-130 – is incorrect because Figure 1 illustrates that 14% of people fall within this range as opposed to the range of 85-100 which represents 34% of people. Thus, it is unlikely that a random person’s IQ will fall within the 115-130 range. Option D. 130-145 – is incorrect because Figure 1 illustrates that only 2% of people fall within the range of 130-145. Thus, it is unlikely that a random person’s IQ will fall within this range.

question.text: Which of the following factors inadvertently prevented an individual from demonstrating their innate abilities on early tests conducted by Alfred Binet?

explanation.concept_text: Paragraph 6 states: “Stanford-Binet Intelligence Test, which is an American adaptation of Binet’s original French test. Psychologist David Wechsler did not like either of these tests as they required a good grasp of language to do well. What if someone had a reading disability or poor linguistic education? The resulting IQ test is known as the Weschler Intelligence Scale, and consists of two parts.” Weschler recognized that an apparent limitation in Binet’s test is that it did not address the factor of literacy. If someone had a reading disability or poor linguistic education, they were bound to do worse in Binet’s test. Thus, literacy can unknowingly prevent an individual from displaying their innate abilities on this test. Therefore, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Higher education – is incorrect because paragraph 2 states that “Binet began to understand that many people were considered smart because they understood the laws of physics or could recite Shakespearean literature. He considered these skills as outcomes of higher education, which made him wonder if there was a way to measure intelligence regardless of education.” Additionally, paragraph 3 states: “Binet’s original test for children had them put things in order and identify patterns, to which education offered no advantage.” Thus, someone’s education is not a factor that would prevent them from displaying their innate abilities on Binet’s test. Option B. Physical Strength – is incorrect because physical strength is never mentioned in the passage, it is unclear how this factor affects intelligence in any way. Thus, there is no evidence to support this option, making it incorrect. Option D. Physical health – is incorrect because physical health is never mentioned in the passage, it is unclear how this factor affects intelligence in any way. Thus, there is no evidence to support this option, making it incorrect. Option E. Thus, there is no evidence to support this option, making it incorrect.

passage.title: Passage 3
passage.text:
(1). Alfred Binet was unlike other Psychologists at the beginning of the 20 th century. The primary focus of psychology at this time was understanding people who were different from the norm. This included why people felt, acted, or thought in unusual ways. Interestingly, Binet was interested in the very opposite of this notion. He wanted to define what was normal, specifically relating to mental capacity and intelligence. What defines an individual as highly intelligent, and where is the average?

(2). Binet began to understand that many people were considered smart because they understood the laws of physics or could recite Shakespearean literature. He considered these skills as outcomes of higher education, which made him wonder if there was a way to measure intelligence regardless of education.

(3). Binet proceeded to design a test to quantify the innate ability of a normal person. This would help French officials identify students who were in danger of falling behind in school. This innate ability was, and still is, referred to as an intelligence quotient, or IQ for short. Binet’s original test for children had them put things in order and identify patterns, to which education offered no advantage.

(4). IQ is reported as a number on a scale, with 100 being the average for an individual’s age. Consider a 7-year-old boy who scores an IQ of 100 on Binet’s test. This boy is theoretically able to perform Binet’s tasks just as well as most other 7-year-olds. However, if he were to score a 110, he would be above average for his age. Mathematically, a large random sample of 7-year-old kids would have an average IQ score of 100. This marks the 50 th percentile, as a score of 100 will be higher than 50% of the group. 34% of the kids would have an IQ score between 85 and 100, and another 34% of the kids would score between 100 and 115. This means that 68% of the kids will score within 85 and 115. All the percentage ranges below an IQ score of 115 add up to 84%. This means that this score marks the 84 th percentile, as 84% of individuals will score below 115. This symmetrical standard distribution of test scores is commonly known as the bell curve (Figure 1).

Figure 1: Standard bell curve of IQ test scores

(5). Theoretically, an individual’s IQ will stay the same throughout one’s life, as there are different tests for different ages. A 7-year-old will be scored against the average 7-year-old. When that same child is 10 years old, he will be scored against other 10-year-old children with more challenging questions, or more difficult grading schemes. The type of IQ test also plays an important role, as there are multiple tests currently available.

(6). Lewis Terman of Stanford University developed the Stanford-Binet Intelligence Test, which is an American adaptation of Binet’s original French test. Psychologist David Wechsler did not like either of these tests as they required a good grasp of language to do well. What if someone had a reading disability or poor linguistic education? The resulting IQ test is known as the Weschler Intelligence Scale, and consists of two parts. The first part is much like the Stanford-Binet test; it is called a verbal IQ score and is often close to a person’s Stanford-Binet IQ. The second part includes tasks that don’t require people to be good with words. For instance, identifying patterns in pictures is one of several wordless tasks. This part yields a performance IQ score, which may be extremely different from one’s verbal IQ score. Discrepancies in these two scores may help psychologists and teachers identify the presence of a language deficiency or reading disability. A third and final IQ score produced by the Wechsler scale is overall IQ, which averages the performance IQ and verbal IQ. Consistently, all IQ tests will exhibit a standard bell curve of scores within a random sample, with 100 always representing the average score.

(7). Standardized reading comprehension assessments also score participants in a standard bell curve with an average of 100, but they do not indicate IQ. They merely indicate a global view of a child’s reading ability, which may provide useful instructions and interventions to improve reading capabilities. The Simple View of Reading (SVR) is a framework that identifies word recognition and oral language comprehension as the two primary components involved in reading comprehension. An SVR standardized reading comprehension assessment will thereby grade students on these two components.

(8). Word recognition encompasses phonological awareness, automaticity of word recognition, and other phonic skills. There are three subtests that grade these skills: (1) word attack, which has students sound out gibberish words; (2) word identification, which analyzes a student’s verbal pronunciation while reading a passage; (3) spelling, which has students spell simple and complex words. The scores of these three tests will indicate how a student’s word recognition abilities compare to other students of the same age.

(9). Oral Language comprehension encompasses oral vocabulary, morphology, sentence comprehension, and pragmatic language. There are three subtests that grade these skills: (1) listening comprehension, which tests a student’s ability to recall a verbal story; (2) reading comprehension, which tests a student’s ability to recall a written passage; (3) vocabulary, which tests the quantity of words that a student knows. The scores of these three tests indicate how a student’s oral language comprehension abilities compare to other students of the same age.

(10). Consider Abby, a fourth-grade student who recently completed an SVR standardized reading comprehension assessment (Table 1). Abby can effectively recall details of stories read aloud, recall details from written passages, and is able to consistently use accurate vocabulary in speech. On the other hand, her reading is not fluent, her reading pace is slow, she frequently sounds out written words, and her spelling is below average. Her test results indicate weak word recognition skills and strong oral language comprehension skills (Table 1).

Table 1: Abby’s test results

Primary Skill

Subtest

Score

Oral Language Comprehension

72

(11). Abby’s test scores, which indicate strong oral language comprehension skills and poor word recognition skills, is referred to as a first profile reading difficulty. Students under this profile may perform well in class discussions, but will have trouble on spelling and reading tests. In severe cases, this profile can indicate the presence of SLD/Dyslexia. A second profile reading disorder is classified by the opposite; strong word recognition skills and weak oral language comprehension. Students under this profile may perform well on spelling and reading tests, but will have difficulties expressing their ideas and comprehending verbal lectures. Finally, a third profile reading difficulty is indicated by a mix of strengths and weaknesses in both word recognition and oral language comprehension, with no clear discrepancy between the two.

(12). Importantly, taking a standardized test is completely optional. Parents do not necessarily need their children to take any of these tests. However, the information received from the results of a child’s performance can provide information regarding their intellectual development and potential, which may identify the need for additional educational resources that target areas of weakness.

question.text: A standardized reading comprehension assessment indicates a student’s IQ. Standardized testing may recognize the need for individualized programs and interventions to improve areas of weakness.

options.label: C.
options.text: The first statement is TRUE. The second statement is FALSE

options.label: D.
options.text: The first statement is FALSE. The second statement is TRUE

correct_answer_text: The first statement is FALSE. The second statement is TRUE

explanation.concept_text: Paragraph 7 states: “Standardized reading comprehension assessments also score participants in a standard bell curve with an average of 100, but they do not indicate IQ. They merely indicate a global view of a child’s reading ability, which may provide useful instructions and interventions to improve reading capabilities.” Thus, the first statement is false because standardized reading comprehension assessments do NOT indicate a student’s IQ. However, the second statement is true because these assessments can be used to identify the need for useful instruction and interventions to improve one’s area of weakness, particularly in reading capabilities. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Both statements are TRUE – is incorrect because paragraph 7 states that “Standardized reading comprehension assessments also score participants in a standard bell curve with an average of 100, but they do not indicate IQ. They merely indicate a global view of a child’s reading ability, which may provide useful instructions and interventions to improve reading capabilities.” Thus, although the second statement is indeed true, the first one is false because standardized reading comprehension assessments do NOT indicate a student’s IQ. Option B. Both statements are FALSE – is incorrect because paragraph 7 states that “Standardized reading comprehension assessments also score participants in a standard bell curve with an average of 100, but they do not indicate IQ. They merely indicate a global view of a child’s reading ability, which may provide useful instructions and interventions to improve reading capabilities.” Thus, although the first statement is indeed false, the second statement is true because these assessments can be used to identify the need for useful instruction and interventions to improve one’s area of weakness, particularly in reading capabilities. Option C. The first statement is TRUE. The second statement is FALSE – is incorrect because paragraph 7 states: “Standardized reading comprehension assessments […] do not indicate IQ…” which makes the first statement false.  On the other hand, paragraph 7 also states that these assessments “…may provide useful instructions and interventions to improve reading capabilities.” This makes the second statement true because these assessments can be used to identify the need for useful instruction and interventions to improve one’s area of weakness, particularly in reading capabilities.

question.text: An individual’s IQ will theoretically stay the same throughout their life because there are different tests for each age group.

options.label: A.
options.text: The statement is correct, but the reason is NOT

options.label: B.
options.text: The statement is NOT correct, but the reason is correct

options.label: C.
options.text: Both the statement and reason are correct

options.label: D.
options.text: Both the statement and reason are NOT correct

correct_answer_text: Both the statement and reason are correct

explanation.poe_text: Option A. The statement is correct, but the reason is NOT – is incorrect because paragraph 5 states that “…an individual’s IQ will stay the same throughout one’s life, as there are different tests for different ages.” Thus, the statement and reasoning are both correct. Option B. The statement is NOT correct, but the reason is correct – is incorrect because paragraph 5 states that “…an individual’s IQ will stay the same throughout one’s life, as there are different tests for different ages.” Thus, the statement and reasoning are both correct. Option D. Both the statement and reason are NOT correct – is incorrect because paragraph 5 states that “…an individual’s IQ will stay the same throughout one’s life, as there are different tests for different ages.” Thus, the statement and reasoning are both correct, NOT false.

question.text: Which of the following best describes the author’s tone in regards to standardized testing?

explanation.concept_text: The author begins the passage by introducing Binet and his idea to measure intelligence in paragraphs 1 and 2. The author then goes into detail describing IQ tests, what their scores represent, and the concept of standardization in paragraphs 3 to 5. The passage then addresses the other forms of intelligence testing and provides an example in paragraphs 6 to 10, and concludes with a brief discussion on profile reading difficulties (paragraph 11). Evidently, the passage focuses on describing standardized testing. To accomplish this, the author employs an informative tone. They do not appear to take any specific side of an argument nor do they seem to advocate strongly for a position. Rather, they are merely stating facts and explaining concepts in depth. Hence, the author’s tone is informative. Therefore, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Indifferent – is incorrect because indifference is being unconcerned. Although the overall neutral tone of the passage may suggest that the author does not care too strongly about this topic, there is no indication that the author is unconcerned. In paragraph 1, the author states: “Alfred Binet was unlike other Psychologists at the beginning of the 20 th century. The primary focus of psychology at this time was understanding people who were different from the norm. […] Interestingly, Binet was interested in the very opposite of this notion. He wanted to define what was normal, specifically relating to mental capacity and intelligence. What defines an individual as highly intelligent, and where is the average?” By using rhetorical questions and words such as “interestingly”, the author appears to be somewhat intrigued by the topic. On the other hand, claiming that they are indifferent is too strong of an assumption because there is no passage evidence to suggest this. Option B. Pessimistic – is incorrect because pessimism is the tendency to view something in a negative, foreboding light. The author does not appear to be pessimistic about standardized testing. On the contrary, paragraph 12 states that “However, the information received from the results of a child’s performance can provide information regarding their intellectual development and potential, which may identify the need for additional educational resources that target areas of weakness.” By claiming that these assessments can have potential benefits, the author discusses standardized testing and its effects in a positive and optimistic light. Thus, the author does NOT employ a negative, pessimistic tone. Option D. Speculative – is incorrect because a speculative tone involves demonstrating doubt about the subject manner. However, the author does not appear to this at all. Although the author does explain the limitations of traditional IQ testing in paragraph 6, they reconcile this by discussing other forms of tests. Thus, the author does NOT employ a speculative tone. Option E. Hypothetical – is incorrect because a hypothetical tone would involve having some degree of uncertainty. However, the author states the information in the passage as matters of facts. There is no doubt about the subject manner. Although the author does explain the limitations of traditional IQ testing in paragraph 6, they reconcile this by discussing other forms of tests. Thus, the author does NOT employ a hypothetical tone.

There are three subtests that grade these skills: (1) listening comprehension, which tests a student’s ability to recall a verbal story; (2) reading comprehension, which tests a student’s ability to recall a written passage; (3) vocabulary, which tests the quantity of words that a student knows. The scores of these three tests indicate how a student’s oral language comprehension abilities compare to other students of the same age.

(10). Consider Abby, a fourth-grade student who recently completed an SVR standardized reading comprehension assessment (Table 1). Abby can effectively recall details of stories read aloud, recall details from written passages, and is able to consistently use accurate vocabulary in speech. On the other hand, her reading is not fluent, her reading pace is slow, she frequently sounds out written words, and her spelling is below average. Her test results indicate weak word recognition skills and strong oral language comprehension skills (Table 1).
