(11). Abby’s test scores, which indicate strong oral language comprehension skills and poor word recognition skills, is referred to as a first profile reading difficulty. Students under this profile may perform well in class discussions, but will have trouble on spelling and reading tests. In severe cases, this profile can indicate the presence of SLD/Dyslexia. A second profile reading disorder is classified by the opposite; strong word recognition skills and weak oral language comprehension. Students under this profile may perform well on spelling and reading tests, but will have difficulties expressing their ideas and comprehending verbal lectures. Finally, a third profile reading difficulty is indicated by a mix of strengths and weaknesses in both word recognition and oral language comprehension, with no clear discrepancy between the two.

(12). Importantly, taking a standardized test is completely optional. Parents do not necessarily need their children to take any of these tests. However, the information received from the results of a child’s performance can provide information regarding their intellectual development and potential, which may identify the need for additional educational resources that target areas of weakness.

question.text: Which of the following would represent the score of a student with a second profile reading disorder on the vocabulary section of a standardized reading comprehension test?

explanation.concept_text: Paragraph 11 states: “A second profile reading disorder is classified by the opposite; strong word recognition skills and weak oral language comprehension. Students under this profile may perform well on spelling and reading tests, but will have difficulties expressing their ideas and comprehending verbal lectures.” The student in the question will have strong word recognition skills but weak oral language comprehension. Paragraph 9 states: “Oral Language comprehension encompasses oral vocabulary, […] (3) vocabulary, which tests the quantity of words that a student knows.” Since the student has weak oral language comprehension, it is safe to assume that their vocabulary is weak as well. Thus, they will likely score low on this section. The lowest score indicated in the options is 85. Therefore, Option A is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. 100 – is incorrect because paragraph 11 states that “A second profile reading disorder is classified by the opposite; strong word recognition skills and weak oral language comprehension,” and paragraph 9 demonstrates that “Oral Language comprehension encompasses oral vocabulary.” Thus, it is safe to assume that someone with this disorder will have a weak vocabulary. Such a student will score low, NOT average (i.e. 100), on this section. Option C. 115 – is incorrect because paragraph 11 states that “A second profile reading disorder is classified by the opposite; strong word recognition skills and weak oral language comprehension,” and paragraph 9 demonstrates that “Oral Language comprehension encompasses oral vocabulary.” Thus, it is safe to assume that someone with this disorder will have a weak vocabulary. Such a student will score low, NOT above average (i.e. 115), on this section. Option D. 130 – is incorrect because paragraph 11 states that “A second profile reading disorder is classified by the opposite; strong word recognition skills and weak oral language comprehension,” and paragraph 9 demonstrates that “Oral Language comprehension encompasses oral vocabulary.” Thus, it is safe to assume that someone with this disorder will have a weak vocabulary. Such a student will score low, NOT above average (i.e. 130), on this section. Option E. 145 – is incorrect because paragraph 11 states that “A second profile reading disorder is classified by the opposite; strong word recognition skills and weak oral language comprehension,” and paragraph 9 demonstrates that “Oral Language comprehension encompasses oral vocabulary.” Thus, it is safe to assume that someone with this disorder will have a weak vocabulary. Such a student will score low, NOT above average (i.e. 145), on this section.

passage.title: Passage 3
passage.text:
(1). Alfred Binet was unlike other Psychologists at the beginning of the 20 th century. The primary focus of psychology at this time was understanding people who were different from the norm. This included why people felt, acted, or thought in unusual ways. Interestingly, Binet was interested in the very opposite of this notion. He wanted to define what was normal, specifically relating to mental capacity and intelligence. What defines an individual as highly intelligent, and where is the average?

(2). Binet began to understand that many people were considered smart because they understood the laws of physics or could recite Shakespearean literature. He considered these skills as outcomes of higher education, which made him wonder if there was a way to measure intelligence regardless of education.

(3). Binet proceeded to design a test to quantify the innate ability of a normal person. This would help French officials identify students who were in danger of falling behind in school. This innate ability was, and still is, referred to as an intelligence quotient, or IQ for short. Binet’s original test for children had them put things in order and identify patterns, to which education offered no advantage.

(4). IQ is reported as a number on a scale, with 100 being the average for an individual’s age. Consider a 7-year-old boy who scores an IQ of 100 on Binet’s test. This boy is theoretically able to perform Binet’s tasks just as well as most other 7-year-olds. However, if he were to score a 110, he would be above average for his age. Mathematically, a large random sample of 7-year-old kids would have an average IQ score of 100. This marks the 50 th percentile, as a score of 100 will be higher than 50% of the group. 34% of the kids would have an IQ score between 85 and 100, and another 34% of the kids would score between 100 and 115. This means that 68% of the kids will score within 85 and 115. All the percentage ranges below an IQ score of 115 add up to 84%. This means that this score marks the 84 th percentile, as 84% of individuals will score below 115. This symmetrical standard distribution of test scores is commonly known as the bell curve (Figure 1).

Figure 1: Standard bell curve of IQ test scores

(5). Theoretically, an individual’s IQ will stay the same throughout one’s life, as there are different tests for different ages. A 7-year-old will be scored against the average 7-year-old. When that same child is 10 years old, he will be scored against other 10-year-old children with more challenging questions, or more difficult grading schemes. The type of IQ test also plays an important role, as there are multiple tests currently available.

(6). Lewis Terman of Stanford University developed the Stanford-Binet Intelligence Test, which is an American adaptation of Binet’s original French test. Psychologist David Wechsler did not like either of these tests as they required a good grasp of language to do well. What if someone had a reading disability or poor linguistic education? The resulting IQ test is known as the Weschler Intelligence Scale, and consists of two parts. The first part is much like the Stanford-Binet test; it is called a verbal IQ score and is often close to a person’s Stanford-Binet IQ. The second part includes tasks that don’t require people to be good with words. For instance, identifying patterns in pictures is one of several wordless tasks. This part yields a performance IQ score, which may be extremely different from one’s verbal IQ score. Discrepancies in these two scores may help psychologists and teachers identify the presence of a language deficiency or reading disability. A third and final IQ score produced by the Wechsler scale is overall IQ, which averages the performance IQ and verbal IQ. Consistently, all IQ tests will exhibit a standard bell curve of scores within a random sample, with 100 always representing the average score.

(7). Standardized reading comprehension assessments also score participants in a standard bell curve with an average of 100, but they do not indicate IQ. They merely indicate a global view of a child’s reading ability, which may provide useful instructions and interventions to improve reading capabilities. The Simple View of Reading (SVR) is a framework that identifies word recognition and oral language comprehension as the two primary components involved in reading comprehension. An SVR standardized reading comprehension assessment will thereby grade students on these two components.

(8). Word recognition encompasses phonological awareness, automaticity of word recognition, and other phonic skills. There are three subtests that grade these skills: (1) word attack, which has students sound out gibberish words; (2) word identification, which analyzes a student’s verbal pronunciation while reading a passage; (3) spelling, which has students spell simple and complex words. The scores of these three tests will indicate how a student’s word recognition abilities compare to other students of the same age.

(9). Oral Language comprehension encompasses oral vocabulary, morphology, sentence comprehension, and pragmatic language. There are three subtests that grade these skills: (1) listening comprehension, which tests a student’s ability to recall a verbal story; (2) reading comprehension, which tests a student’s ability to recall a written passage; (3) vocabulary, which tests the quantity of words that a student knows. The scores of these three tests indicate how a student’s oral language comprehension abilities compare to other students of the same age.

(10). Consider Abby, a fourth-grade student who recently completed an SVR standardized reading comprehension assessment (Table 1). Abby can effectively recall details of stories read aloud, recall details from written passages, and is able to consistently use accurate vocabulary in speech. On the other hand, her reading is not fluent, her reading pace is slow, she frequently sounds out written words, and her spelling is below average. Her test results indicate weak word recognition skills and strong oral language comprehension skills (Table 1).

Table 1: Abby’s test results

Primary Skill

Subtest

(11). Abby’s test scores, which indicate strong oral language comprehension skills and poor word recognition skills, is referred to as a first profile reading difficulty. Students under this profile may perform well in class discussions, but will have trouble on spelling and reading tests. In severe cases, this profile can indicate the presence of SLD/Dyslexia. A second profile reading disorder is classified by the opposite; strong word recognition skills and weak oral language comprehension. Students under this profile may perform well on spelling and reading tests, but will have difficulties expressing their ideas and comprehending verbal lectures. Finally, a third profile reading difficulty is indicated by a mix of strengths and weaknesses in both word recognition and oral language comprehension, with no clear discrepancy between the two.

(12). Importantly, taking a standardized test is completely optional. Parents do not necessarily need their children to take any of these tests. However, the information received from the results of a child’s performance can provide information regarding their intellectual development and potential, which may identify the need for additional educational resources that target areas of weakness.

question.text: Based on the following sample score report, under which of the following categories would this student be classified? Table 2: Sample Report Card

explanation.concept_text: Paragraph 11 states: “…a third profile reading difficulty is indicated by a mix of strengths and weaknesses in both word recognition and oral language comprehension, with no clear discrepancy between the two.” Since the student in the question scored more or less the same in both oral language comprehension and word recognition sections, they most likely have the third profile reading disorder. Therefore, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. First profile reading disorder – is incorrect because paragraph 11 states that “…test scores, which indicate strong oral language comprehension skills and poor word recognition skills, is referred to as a first profile reading difficulty.” If the student in the question had the first profile reading disorder, they would have scored high on oral language comprehension but low on word recognition. However, they scored high in some areas of both sections and low in some areas of both sections. Thus, their results are not indicative of the first profile reading disorder. Rather, since they demonstrate a “…mix of strengths and weaknesses in both word recognition and oral language comprehension, with no clear discrepancy between the two…” (Paragraph 11), they most likely have the third profile reading disorder. Option B. Second profile reading disorder – is incorrect because paragraph 11 states that “A second profile reading disorder is classified by the opposite; strong word recognition skills and weak oral language comprehension. Students under this profile may perform well on spelling and reading tests, but will have difficulties expressing their ideas and comprehending verbal lectures.” If the student in the question had the second profile reading disorder, they would have scored low on oral language comprehension but high on word recognition. However, they scored high in some areas of both sections and low in some areas of both sections. Thus, their results are not indicative of the second profile reading disorder. Rather, since they demonstrate a “…mix of strengths and weaknesses in both word recognition and oral language comprehension, with no clear discrepancy between the two…” (Paragraph 11), they most likely have the third profile reading disorder. Option D. Fourth profile reading disorder – is incorrect because there is no mention of a fourth profile reading disorder in the passage. Thus, this option cannot be correct.

question.text: Which of the following statements, if true, would most challenge the main idea of the passage?

options.label: A.
options.text: Standardized testing should be a requirement for all primary school students

options.label: B.
options.text: Standardized testing is minimally effective as intelligence is primarily genetics-based

options.label: C.
options.text: Standardized testing is problematic as it can make pupils ashamed of their limitations

options.label: D.
options.text: Standardized testing is non-compulsory and is very useful

options.label: E.
options.text: Standardized testing must be continually refined to ensure it stays applicable

correct_answer_text: Standardized testing is minimally effective as intelligence is primarily genetics-based

explanation.concept_text: This question is asking us to identify the statement that would weaken the author’s argument. In paragraph 7 the author writes: “They [standardized reading comprehension assessments] merely indicate a global view of a child’s reading ability, which may provide useful instructions and interventions to improve reading capabilities.” Additionally, paragraph 12 states: “…the information received from the results of a child’s performance can provide information regarding their intellectual development and potential, which may identify the need for additional educational resources that target areas of weakness.” Thus, the author is making the argument that standardized testing can be useful because it can lead to interventions to improve a student’s intelligence. If, however, intelligence was largely based on genetics and could not be improved through interventions, then the author’s argument that these tests are useful would be severely weakened. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Standardized testing should be a requirement for all primary school students – is incorrect because although the author states that standardized testing is optional in paragraph 12, they follow-up this assertion with the claim that such tests “…provide information regarding their [students’] intellectual development and potential, which may identify the need for additional educational resources that target areas of weakness.” Evidently, the author views standardized tests to be somewhat useful because they allow for the identification of students’ weaknesses and development of interventions. Thus, this option does not undermine nor weaken the author’s argument. Option C. Standardized testing is problematic as it can make pupils ashamed of their limitations – is incorrect because in paragraph 12 the author writes that standardized tests “…provide information regarding their [students’] intellectual development and potential, which may identify the need for additional educational resources that target areas of weakness.” Thus, the author views standardized tests to be somewhat useful because they allow for the identification of student’s weaknesses and development of interventions. The student feeling shame because of their weakness does not weaken the author’s argument that such tests are useful because they allow for the development of interventions. Option D. Standardized testing is non-compulsory and is very useful – is incorrect because standardized testing being optional and beneficial is discussed in paragraph 12 when the author writes that these tests “…provide information regarding their [students’] intellectual development and potential, which may identify the need for additional educational resources that target areas of weakness.” Thus, this option would NOT weaken the author’s argument that such tests are useful because they allow for the development of interventions. Option E. Standardized testing must be continually refined to ensure it stays applicable – is incorrect because the central argument made by the author is that such tests are useful because they allow for the development of interventions. This option does not undermine this central argument. If the tests were in need of constant improvement to maintain relevancy, it would not affect the claim regarding their usefulness.

question.text: Which of the following is a benefit of IQ testing mentioned in the passage?

options.label: A.
options.text: It facilitates early identification of at-risk students

options.label: B.
options.text: It allows students who have above-average abilities to be recognized

options.label: C.
options.text: It has enhanced assessment systems in schools

options.label: D.
options.text: It aided the French military in ranking their officers

options.label: E.
options.text: It contributed to French literature in Psychology

correct_answer_text: It facilitates early identification of at-risk students

explanation.concept_text: Paragraph 3 states: “Binet proceeded to design a test to quantify the innate ability of a normal person. This would help French officials identify students who were in danger of falling behind in school. This innate ability was, and still is, referred to as an intelligence quotient, or IQ for short.” Thus, a benefit of IQ tests is that it allows for the identification of students who are at risk of falling behind in school. Therefore, Option A is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. It allows students who have above-average abilities to be recognized – is incorrect because paragraph 3 states that IQ tests “…would help French officials identify students who were in danger of falling behind in school.” Although identifying students who have extraordinary abilities is possible through this test, it is not mentioned in the passage as a benefit of IQ testing. Rather, the author states that this test allows for the identification of students who are at risk of falling behind in school. Option C. It has enhanced assessment systems in schools – is incorrect because the passage never discusses a school’s grading system. Thus, it is unclear how IQ testing would have improved the grading system in schools. Rather, the author mentions that a benefit of IQ testing is that it “…would help French officials identify students who were in danger of falling behind in school.” (Paragraph 3). Option D. It aided the French military in ranking their officers – is incorrect because the passage never discusses the French military ranking system. Thus, it is unclear how IQ testing would have improved helped the French military rank their officers. Rather, the author mentions that a benefit of IQ testing is that it “…would help French officials identify students who were in danger of falling behind in school.” (Paragraph 3). Option E. It contributed to French literature in Psychology – is incorrect because although Alfred Binet was a psychologist, the passage never discusses how developing IQ tests contributed to French literature in Psychology. Thus, it is unclear how this would be a benefit of IQ testing. Rather, the author mentions that a benefit of IQ testing is that it “…would help French officials identify students who were in danger of falling behind in school.” (Paragraph 3).
